question:
Question 1 Water enters a tube of diameter, [latex]D = 60 mm[/latex] with mass flow rate of [latex]0.01 kg s^{-1}[/latex] as shown in the figure below. The inlet mean temperature is [latex]T_{m,i}= 293 K[/latex]  and the uniform heat flux at the surface of the tube is [latex]2000 W m^{-2}[/latex]. For the exit mean temperature of [latex]T_{m,o}= 353 K[/latex], the length of the tube, [latex]L[/latex] is __________ m (rounded off to
1 decimal place). Use the specific heat of water as [latex] 4181 J kg^{-1} K^{-1} [/latex].
solution: Given: Mass flow rate: [latex] \dot{m} = 0.01 , \text{kg/s} [/latex] Specific heat of water: [latex] c_p = 4181 ,   J kg^{-1} K^{-1}  [/latex] Inlet mean temperature: [latex] T_{m,i} = 293 , \text{K} [/latex] Outlet mean temperature: [latex] T_{m,o} = 353 , \text{K} [/latex] Surface heat flux: [latex] q'' = 2000 , \text{W/m}^2 [/latex] Tube diameter: [latex] D = 60 , \text{mm} = 0.06 , \text{m} [/latex] Step 1: Calculate heat gained by water [latex] Q = \dot{m} \cdot c_p \cdot (T_{m,o} - T_{m,i}) [/latex] [latex] Q = 0.01 \cdot 4181 \cdot (353 - 293) = 0.01 \cdot 4181 \cdot 60 = 2508.6 , \text{W} [/latex] Step 2: Calculate surface area of tube for heat transfer [latex] A = \pi D L [/latex] Heat input through the wall: [latex] Q = q'' \cdot A = q'' \cdot \pi D L [/latex] Step 3: Solve for [latex] L [/latex] [latex] 2508.6 = 2000 \cdot \pi \cdot 0.06 \cdot L [/latex] [latex] L = \frac{2508.6}{2000 \cdot \pi \cdot 0.06} \approx \frac{2508.6}{376.99} \approx 6.655 , \text{m} [/latex] Final Answer: [latex] \boxed{6.7 , \text{m}} [/latex] (rounded off to 1 decimal place)

question:
Question 2 Consider a cylindrical furnace of 5 m diameter and 5 m length with bottom, top and
curved surfaces maintained at uniform temperatures of 800 K, 1500 K and 500 K,
respectively. The view factor between the bottom and top surfaces, [latex]F_{12}[/latex] is 0.2. The magnitude of net radiation heat transfer rate between the bottom surface and the
curved surface is __________ kW (rounded off to 1 decimal place). All surfaces of
the furnace can be assumed as black. The Stefan-Boltzmann constant, [latex] \sigma=5.67 \times 10^{-8} W m ^{-2} K^{-4}[/latex].
solution: Given: Diameter of cylinder [latex] D = 5 , m [/latex] Length of cylinder [latex] L = 5 , m [/latex] Temperatures: Bottom surface (1): [latex] T_1 = 800 , K [/latex] Top surface (2): [latex] T_2 = 1500 , K [/latex] Curved surface (3): [latex] T_3 = 500 , K [/latex] View factor [latex] F_{12} = 0.2 [/latex] → From bottom to top Surfaces are black → Emissivity [latex] \varepsilon = 1 [/latex] Stefan-Boltzmann constant: [latex] \sigma = 5.67 \times 10^{-8} , W/m^2K^4 [/latex] Step 1: Surface Areas Area of bottom (1): [latex] A_1 = \frac{\pi D^2}{4} = \frac{\pi \times 5^2}{4} = 19.635 , m^2 [/latex] Step 2: View Factor from Bottom to Curved Surface Using summation rule: [latex] F_{11} + F_{12} + F_{13} = 1 [/latex] Since a surface can’t see itself in diffuse radiation: [latex] F_{11} = 0 [/latex] So, [latex] F_{13} = 1 - F_{12} = 1 - 0.2 = 0.8 [/latex] Step 3: Radiation heat transfer from bottom to curved surface [latex] Q_{13} = A_1 \cdot F_{13} \cdot \sigma \cdot (T_1^4 - T_3^4) [/latex] Substitute values: [latex] Q_{13} = 19.635 \times 0.8 \times 5.67 \times 10^{-8} \times (800^4 - 500^4) [/latex] Calculate powers: [latex] 800^4 = 4.096 \times 10^{11}, \quad 500^4 = 6.25 \times 10^{10} [/latex] [latex] (T_1^4 - T_3^4) = 4.096 \times 10^{11} - 6.25 \times 10^{10} = 3.471 \times 10^{11} [/latex] Now calculate: [latex] Q_{13} = 19.635 \times 0.8 \times 5.67 \times 10^{-8} \times 3.471 \times 10^{11} [/latex] First calculate constant product: [latex] 19.635 \times 0.8 = 15.708 [/latex] [latex] 5.67 \times 10^{-8} \times 3.471 \times 10^{11} = 19687.57 [/latex] Now multiply: [latex] Q_{13} = 15.708 \times 19687.57 = 309214.2 , W = 309.2 , kW [/latex] Final Answer: [latex] \boxed{309.2 , \text{kW}} [/latex] (rounded off to 1 decimal place)

question: Question 3 Let a spherical block of ice at [latex]-7 ^{\circ} C [/latex] be exposed to atmospheric air at [latex]30^{\circ} C[/latex] with the gravitational direction as shown in the figure below.  What will be the overall direction of air flow in this situation?
solution: Step 1: Understanding the Given Situation A spherical block of ice at -7°C is surrounded by atmospheric air at 30°C. The figure shows gravitational direction acting downward. We need to determine the overall direction of air flow due to this temperature difference. Step 2: Analyzing Air Flow Mechanism The air in contact with the ice block cools down and becomes denser. Denser air moves downward due to gravity, creating a convective current. Warmer surrounding air replaces the cooler air that moves downward, continuing the cycle. Step 3: Checking the Given Options (A) Upward → Incorrect. The cold air sinks, so the flow is not upward. (B) Downward → Correct ✅ Cold air descends due to increased density. (C) NO motion → Incorrect. There is natural convection due to temperature difference. (D) Sideward → Incorrect. While some sideward motion may occur, the dominant flow is downward.

question: Question 4 Consider a hemispherical furnace of diameter [latex]D[/latex] [latex]=6 \mathrm{~m}[/latex] with a flat base. The dome of the furnace has an emissivity of 0.7 and the flat base is a blackbody. The base and the dome are maintained at uniform temperature of [latex]300 \mathrm{~K}[/latex] and [latex]1200 \mathrm{~K}[/latex], respectively. Under steady state conditions, the rate of radiation heat transfer from the dome to be base is _______ [latex]k W[/latex]. (rounded off to the nearest integer). Use Stefan-Boltzmann constant [latex]=5.67 \times 10^{-8}[/latex] [latex]\mathrm{W} /\left(\mathrm{m}^{2} \mathrm{~K}^{4}\right)[/latex].
solution:
[latex]\mathrm{F}_{11}=0[/latex] [latex]\mathrm{F}_{12}=1[/latex] From reciprocity theorem : [latex]
\begin{aligned}
& \mathrm{A}_{1} \mathrm{~F}_{12}=\mathrm{A}_{2} \mathrm{~F}_{21} \\
& \mathrm{~F}_{21}=\frac{\mathrm{A}_{1} \mathrm{~F}_{12}}{\mathrm{~A}_{2}}=\frac{\pi \mathrm{R}^{2} \times 1}{2 \pi \mathrm{R}^{2}} \times 1=0.5 \\
& \mathrm{Q}_{\text {net }}=\mathrm{A}_{2}\left(\mathrm{~F}_{\mathrm{g}}\right)_{2} \times \sigma_{\mathrm{b}} \times\left(\mathrm{T}_{2}^{4}-\mathrm{T}_{1}^{4}\right) \\
&(\mathrm{Fg})_{12}=\frac{1}{\frac{1-\varepsilon_{2}}{\varepsilon_{2}}+\frac{1}{\mathrm{~F}_{21}} \varepsilon_{1}}+\frac{1-\varepsilon}{\varepsilon_{1}} \times \frac{\mathrm{A}_{2}}{\mathrm{~A}_{1}} \\
&=\frac{1}{\frac{1-0.7}{0.7}+\frac{1}{0.5}+0}=0.41176 \\
& \mathrm{Q}_{\text {net }}=2 \pi(3)^{2} \times 0.41176 \times 5.67 \times 10^{-8} \\
& \times\left[1200^{4}-300^{4}\right] \\
&=2726.935 \mathrm{~kW} \approx 2726.94 \mathrm{~kW}
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

question: Question 5 A condenser is used as a heat exchanger in a large steam power plant in which steam is condensed to liquid water. The condenser is a shell and tube heat exchanger which consists of 1 shell and 20,000 tubes. Water flows through each of the tubes at a rate of [latex]1 \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{s}[/latex] with an inlet temperature of [latex]30^{\circ} \mathrm{C}[/latex]. The steam in the condenser shell condenses at the rate of [latex]430 \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{s}[/latex] at a temperature of [latex]50^{\circ} \mathrm{C}[/latex]. If the heat of vaporization is [latex]2.326 \mathrm{MJ} / \mathrm{kg}[/latex] and specific heat of water is [latex]4 \mathrm{~kJ} /[/latex] (kg.K), the effectiveness of the heat exchanger is ______ (rounded off to 3 decimal places).
solution:
no. of tube, [latex]n=20,000[/latex] [latex]
\begin{aligned}
\dot{\mathrm{m}}_{\mathrm{w}} & =1 \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{sec} / \text { per tube } \\
\dot{\mathrm{m}}_{\mathrm{s}} & =430 \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{sec}
\end{aligned}
[/latex] So, [latex]
\begin{aligned}
\dot{\mathrm{M}}_{\mathrm{w}} & =\mathrm{n} \times \dot{\mathrm{m}}_{\mathrm{w}} \\
& =20000 \times 1=20000 \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{sec} \\
\mathrm{LHV} & =2.236 \mathrm{MJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\
\mathrm{C} & =4 \mathrm{~kJ} / \mathrm{kgK} \\
\mathrm{C}_{\min } & =\dot{\mathrm{M}}_{\mathrm{w}} \times \mathrm{C}=20000 \times 4 \\
\varepsilon & =\frac{\dot{m}_{\mathrm{s}} \times \mathrm{LHV}}{\mathrm{C}_{\min }\left(\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{h}_{\mathrm{i}}}-\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{c}_{\mathrm{i}}}\right)} \\
& =\frac{430 \times 2.326 \times 10^{6}}{20000 \times 4(50-30)} \\
\varepsilon & =0.625
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

question: Question 6 Consider a slab of [latex]20 \mathrm{~mm}[/latex] thickness. There is a uniform heat generation of [latex]\dot{q}=100 \mathrm{MW} / \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex] inside the slab. The left and right faces of the slab are maintained at [latex]150^{\circ} \mathrm{C}[/latex] and [latex]110^{\circ} \mathrm{C}[/latex], respectively. The plate has a constant thermal conductivity of 200W/(m.K). Considering a 1-D steady state heat conduction, the location of the maximum temperature from the left face will be at    _____ [latex]\mathrm{mm}[/latex] (answer in integer).

Question 7 Consider a hydrodynamically fully developed laminar flow through a circular pipe with the flow along the axis (i.e. [latex]z[/latex] direction). In the following statements, [latex]T[/latex] is the temperature of the fluid. [latex]T_{w}[/latex] is the wall temperature and [latex]T_{m}[/latex] is the bulk mean temperature of the fluid. Which one the following statements is TRUE ?
solution: In a thermally fully developed flow, the temperature profile will no longer change along length of flow, similar the velocity profile. It means there is no further growth of boundary layer. This is the case of steady state. i.e. [latex]\quad \frac{d T}{d Z}=0[/latex] [latex]\mathrm{N}_{\mathrm{u}}=[/latex] Constant for thermally fully developed flow. [latex]\left(T_{w}-T_{m}\right)[/latex] decays exponential [latex]\frac{d T_{m}}{d_{z}}[/latex] increases exponentially

options.A: For a thermal fully developed flow, [latex]\frac{\partial \mathrm{T}}{\mathrm{dz}}=0[/latex], always.
options.B: For constant wall temperature of the duct, [latex]\frac{\mathrm{d} \mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{m}}}{\mathrm{dz}}=[/latex] constant.
options.C: Nusselt number varies linearly along the [latex]z[/latex] direction for a thermally fully developed flow.
options.D: For constant wall temperature [latex]\left(T_{w} > T_{m}\right)[/latex] of the duct, [latex]\frac{d T_{m}}{d z}[/latex] increases exponentially with distance along [latex]z[/latex] direction.

question: Question 8 Consider incompressible laminar flow over a flat plate with freestream velocity of [latex]\mathrm{u}_{\infty}[/latex]. The Nusselt number corresponding to this flow velocity is [latex]\mathrm{Nu}_{1}[/latex]. If the freestream velocity is doubled, the Nusselt number changes to [latex]\mathrm{Nu}_{2}[/latex]. Choose the correct option [latex]\mathrm{Nu}_{2} / \mathrm{Nu}_{1}[/latex].

Question 9 A plane, solid slab of thickness [latex]L[/latex], shown in the figure, has thermal conductivity [latex]k[/latex] that varies with the spatial coordinate [latex]x[/latex] as [latex]k=A+B x[/latex], where [latex]A[/latex] and [latex]B[/latex] are positive constants [latex](A > 0, B > 0)[/latex]. The slab walls are maintained at fixed temperature of [latex]\mathrm{T}(\mathrm{x}=0)=0[/latex] and [latex]\mathrm{T}(\mathrm{x}=\mathrm{L})=\mathrm{T}_{0} > 0[/latex] . The slab has no internal heat sources. Considering onedimensional heat transfer, which one of the following plots qualitatively depicts the steady-state temperature distribution within the slab?
solution:
Given:  [latex]
k=A+B x
[/latex] [latex]
\dot{\mathrm{q}}_{\mathrm{g}} \rightarrow 0
[/latex] As [latex]\quad \dot{\mathrm{q}}=-\mathrm{kA} \frac{\mathrm{dT}}{\mathrm{dx}}[/latex] or, [latex]\quad \frac{\dot{q}}{\mathrm{~A}}=\mathrm{C}[/latex] [latex]
=-k\left(\frac{d T}{d x}\right) \text { for steady state }
[/latex] So, [latex]\quad-k\left(\frac{d T}{d x}\right)=[/latex] constant or, [latex]-(A+B x) \frac{d T}{d x}=C[/latex] or, [latex]\quad \oint_{0}^{L} d T=-\frac{d x \times C}{(A+B x)}[/latex] 0 [latex]\quad \int_{0}^{T} d T=-C \int_{0}^{L} \frac{d x}{A+B x}[/latex] So, temperature distribution will follow logarithmic curve.

solution:

question:
Question 14 Consider incompressible laminar flow of a constant property Newtonian fluid in
an isothermal circular tube. The flow is steady with fully-developed temperature
and velocity profiles. The Nusselt number for this flow depends on
solution:
Nusselt no. for convection with uniform
temperature circular tubes [latex] Nu_D = 3.66 [/latex] Convection with uniform heat flux for circular

question:
Question 15 Consider a hydrodynamically and thermally
fully-developed, steady fluid flow of 1 kg/s in a
uniformly heated pipe with diameter of 0.1 m and
length of 40 m. A constant heat flux of magnitude 15000 [latex]W/m^2[/latex]
 is imposed on the outer surface of the
pipe. The bulk-mean temperature of the fluid at the
entrance to the pipe is [latex] 200^{\circ}C[/latex]. The Reynolds number [latex](R_e)[/latex] of the flow is 85000,
and the Prandtl number [latex](P_r)[/latex] of the fluid is 5. The
thermal conductivity and the specific heat of
the fluid are 0.08 [latex]W\dot m^{-1} \dot K^{-1}[/latex] and 2600 [latex]J \dot kg^{-1} \dot  K^{-1}[/latex],
respectively. The correlation [latex]N_u = 0.023 Re^{0.8} Pr^{0.4}[/latex]
is applicable, where the Nusselt Number [latex](N_u)[/latex] is
defined on the basis of the pipe diameter. The pipe
surface temperature at the exit is ________ [latex] ^{\circ}C[/latex] 
(round off to the nearest integer).
solution:
[latex]\begin{aligned} 
\dot{m}&=1kg/sec\\ 
Re&=85000\\ 
Pr&=5\\ 
K&=0.08 W/mK\\ 
C&=2600J/kgK\\ 
Nu&=0.023R_e^{0.8}Pr^{0.4}\\ 
Nu&=\frac{hD}{k}\\ 
T_s&=?\\ 
Nu&=\frac{hD}{k}=0.023R_e^{0.8}Pr^{0.4}\\ 
\frac{h \times 0.1}{0.08}&=0.023(85000)^{0.8}(5)^{0.4}\\ 
h&=307.56 W/m^2K\\ 
Q&=qA_s=\dot{m}c_p(T_o-T_i)\\ 
q \pi DL&=\dot{m}c_p(T_o-T_i)\\ 
15000 \times \pi \times0.1 \times 40&=1 \times 2600 \times (T_o-200)\\ 
T_o&=272.5^{\circ}C\\ 
&\text{Newtons law of cooling}\\ 
q&=h(T_s-T_m)\\ 
T_s-T-m=\frac{q}{h}=constant 
\end{aligned}[/latex] At outlet, [latex] x=LT_m=T_o. T=T_s[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} 
q&=h(T_s-T_o)\\ 
T_s-T_o&=\frac{q}{h}\\ 
T_s&=T_o+\frac{q}{h}\\ 
T_s&=272.5+\frac{15000}{307.56}\\ 
T_s&=321.27^{\circ}C\\ 
T_s&=321^{\circ}C 
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 16 Saturated vapor at [latex] 200^{\circ}C[/latex] condenses to saturated
liquid at the rate of 150 kg/s on the shell side
of a heat exchanger (enthalpy of condensation
[latex]  h_{fg} = 2400 kJ/kg[/latex]). A fluid with [latex]C_p
 = 4 kJ\dot kg^{-1} \dot K^{-1}[/latex]
enters at [latex] 100^{\circ}C[/latex] on the tube side. If the effectiveness
of the heat exchanger is 0.9, then the mass flow rate
of the fluid in the tube side is ____ kg/s (in integer).
solution:
Hot fluid [latex]\begin{aligned} 
T_{h1} &=T_{h2}=200^{\circ} C\\ 
\dot{m}_h &=150kg/s \\ 
&= h_{fg}&=2400kj/kg 
\end{aligned}[/latex] Cold fluid [latex]\begin{aligned} 
T_{c1} &=100^{\circ} C\\ 
\in &=0.9\\ 
\dot{m}_c &= ? kg/sec 
\end{aligned}[/latex] If fluid is under phase change then that fluid have in 
finite heat capacity rate. In this case hot fluid is under phase change so 
[latex]C_{max}=\infty [/latex] It means cold fluid have minimum heat capacity 
rate [latex]\begin{aligned} 
c_{min}&=\dot{m}_c c_c\\ 
\in &=\frac{Q_{act}}{Q_{max}}\\ 
0.9&=\frac{\dot{m}_c c_c(T_{c2}-T_{c1})}{c_{min}(T_{h1}-T_{c1})}\\ 
0.9&=\frac{T_{c2}-100}{200-100}\\ 
T_{c2}&=190^{\circ}C\\ 
Q&=\dot{m}_hh_{fg}=\dot{m}_cc_c(T_{c2}-T_{c1})\\ 
150 \times 2400&=\dot{m}_c \times 4 \times (190-100)\\ 
\dot{m}_c&=1000kg/sec 
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 17 Consider steady state, one-dimensional heat
conduction in an infinite slab of thickness
[latex]2L (L = 1 m)[/latex] as shown in the figure. The conductivity
[latex](k)[/latex] of the material varies with temperature as
[latex]k = CT[/latex], where [latex]T[/latex] is the temperature in [latex]K[/latex], and [latex]C[/latex] is a
constant equal to [latex]2 W\dot m^{-1} \dot K^{-2}[/latex]. There is a uniform
heat generation of [latex]1280 kW/m^3[/latex]
 in the slab. If both
faces of the slab are maintained at 600 K, then the
temperature at [latex]x = 0 [/latex] is ________ K (in integer).
solution:
General Heat conduction equation in Cartesian
coordinates is [latex]\frac{\partial }{\partial x}\left ( K_x\frac{\partial T}{\partial x} \right )+\frac{\partial }{\partial y}\left ( K_y\frac{\partial T}{\partial y} \right )\frac{\partial }{\partial z}\left ( K_z\frac{\partial T}{\partial z} \right )+q_g=\rho c\frac{\partial T}{\partial t} [/latex] For one dimensional steady state heat generation
with variable thermal conductivity, the above
equation can be written as [latex]\begin{aligned}
\frac{\partial }{\partial x}\left ( CT\frac{\partial T}{\partial x} \right )+q_g&=0\\
C\frac{\partial }{\partial x}\left ( T\frac{\partial T}{\partial x} \right )+q_g&=0\\
\frac{\partial }{\partial x}\left ( T\frac{\partial T}{\partial x} \right )+\frac{q_g}{C}&=0\\
\frac{\partial }{\partial x}\left ( T\frac{\partial T}{\partial x} \right )&=-\frac{q_g}{C}\\
\int \frac{\partial }{\partial x}\left ( T\frac{\partial T}{\partial x} \right )&=-\int \frac{q_g}{C}\\
\text{For 1-D heat flow}\\
\frac{\partial T}{\partial x}&=\frac{dT }{\partial x}\\
T\frac{dT}{dx}&=-\frac{q_gx}{C}+C_1\\
x=0\;\;\frac{dT}{dx}&=0\;\;C_1=0 \text{ (At centerline)}\\
T\frac{dT}{dx}&=-\frac{q_gx}{C}\\
\int TdT&=\int -\frac{q_gx}{C}dx\\
\frac{T^2}{2}&=\frac{-q_gx^2}{2C}+C_2 . . . (1)\\
T=T_s&=\text{Outside surface temperature}\\
\frac{T_S^2}{2}&=\frac{-q_gL^2}{2C}+C_2\\
C_2&=\frac{T-s^2}{2}+\frac{q_gL^2}{2C}\\
\text{Put }&c_2 \text{ in equation (1)}\\
\frac{T^2}{2}&=\frac{-q_ax^2}{2C}+\frac{T_s^2}{2}+\frac{q_gL^2}{2C}\\
\text{At }&x=0,T=T_{max}\\
\frac{T_{max}^2}{2}&=\frac{T_s^2}{2}+\frac{q_gL^2}{2C}\\
\frac{T_{max}^2}{2}&=\frac{600^2}{2}+\frac{128010^3 \times 1^2}{2 \times 2}\\
T_{max}&=1000K
\end{aligned} [/latex]

question:
Question 18 Wien's law is stated as follows: [latex] \lambda _mT=C [/latex], where [latex] C [/latex]
is 2898 [latex]\mu mK [/latex] and [latex] \lambda _m[/latex] is the wavelength at which the
emissive power of a black body is maximum for
a given temperature [latex] T[/latex]. The spectral hemispherical
emissivity [latex] (\varepsilon _ \lambda)[/latex]  of a surface is shown in the figure
below ([latex] 1\mathring{A}=10^{-10}m [/latex]). The temperature at which the
total hemispherical emissivity will be highest is
__________ K (round off to the nearest integer).
solution:
From the figure we can say that at  [latex] 6000 \mathring{A} [/latex]
wavelength total hemispherical emissivity is
maximum [latex] \lambda _m=6000 \mathring{A} =0.6\mu m[/latex] Wein's law [latex] \lambda _m T=C[/latex] [latex] \lambda _m T=2898 \mu mK[/latex] [latex]  T=\frac{2898}{0.6}=4830K[/latex] Note: In this question, we need to find temperature
at which total hemispherical emissivity will be
highest. But to calculate total hemispherical emissivity
we require additional data like function chart and
emissivity value at particular wavelength. With the use of Wein's law we can find out
temperature at which spectral emissivity is highest
but in question it is asked temperature for total
hemispherical emissivity.

question:
Question 19 Which of the following non-dimensional terms is
an estimate of Nusselt number?

options.A: Ratio of internal thermal resistance of a solid to the boundary layer thermal resistance
options.B: Ratio of the rate at which internal energy is advected to the rate of conduction heat transfer
options.D: Non-dimensional velocity gradient multiplied by Prandtl number

question:
Question 20 During open-heart surgery, a patient?s blood is
cooled down to [latex]25^{\circ}C  [/latex] from [latex]37^{\circ}C  [/latex] using a concentric
tube counter-flow heat exchanger. Water enters the
heat exchanger at [latex]4^{\circ}C  [/latex] and leaves at [latex]18^{\circ}C  [/latex]. Blood
flow rate during the surgery is 5 L/minute.
Use the following fluid properties: [latex] \begin{array}{|c|c|c|} \hline
 \text{Fluid}&  \text{Density }(kg/m^3)&\text{Specific heat (J/kg-K)}\\ \hline
 \text{Blood}& 1050 & 3740\\ \hline
 \text{Water}& 1000 & 4200 \\ \hline
\end{array}  [/latex] Effectiveness of the heat exchanger is _________
(round off to 2 decimal places).
solution:
For preferred heat exchange between load and water. [latex]\begin{aligned} 
Q_{blood}&=Q_{water}\\ 
\dot{m}_h c_h(T_{h_1}-T_{h_2})&=\dot{m}_c c_c(T_{c_2}-T_{c_1})\\ 
\dot{m}_h c_h(37-25)&=\dot{m}_c c_c(18-4)\\ 
12\dot{m}_h c_h&=14\dot{m}_c c_c\\ 
\dot{m}_h c_h&=\frac{14}{12}\dot{m}_c c_c\\ 
\dot{m}_hc_h&=1.167\dot{m}_cc_c\\ 
\dot{m}_hc_h& \lt \dot{m}_cc_c\\ 
\dot{m}_cc_c&=c_{min}, \dot{m}_hc_h=c_{max}\\ 
\varepsilon &=\frac{Q_{act}}{Q_{max}}=\frac{\dot{m}_cc_c(T_{c_2}-T_{c_1})}{c_{min}(T_{h_1}-T_{c_1})}=\frac{T_{c_2}-T_{c_1}}{T_{h_1}-T_{c_1}}\\ 
\varepsilon &=\frac{T_{c_2}-T_{c_1}}{T_{h_1}-T_{c_1}}=\frac{18-4}{37-4}=0.424\\ 
\varepsilon &=0.42 
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 21 Consider a solid slab (thermal conductivity, [latex]k =10 W \dot m^{-1}\dot  K^{-1}[/latex]) with thickness 0.2 m and of infinite extent in the other two directions as shown in the
figure. Surface 2, at 300 K, is exposed to a fluid
flow at a free stream temperature ([latex] T_\infty  [/latex]) of 293 K,
with a convective heat transfer coefficient (h) of
[latex]100 W\dot m^{-2} \dot K^{-1}  [/latex]. Surface 2 is opaque, diffuse and
gray with an emissivity ([latex]\varepsilon  [/latex]) of 0.5 and exchanges
heat by radiation with very large surroundings at
0 K. Radiative heat transfer inside the solid slab
is neglected. The Stefan-Boltzmann constant is
[latex]5.67 \times 10^{-8} W \dot m^{-2}\dot K^{-4}  [/latex]. The temperature [latex]T_1[/latex]
 of Surface
1 of the slab, under steady-state conditions, is
_________ K (round off to the nearest integer).
solution:
[latex]T_\infty =293K,T_{surrounding}=0K, h=100W/m^2K, K_{slab}=10W/mK[/latex] Under steady state [latex]\begin{aligned} 
Q_{stored}&=0\\ 
Q_{in}&=Q_{out}\\ 
Q_{cond}&=Q_{conv}+Q_{rad}\\ 
K\left [ \frac{T_1-T_2}{L} \right ]&=h(T_2-T_\infty )+\varepsilon \sigma (T_2^4-T_{surr}^4)\\ 
10\left [ \frac{T_1-300}{0.2} \right ]&=100(300-293 )+0.5 \times 5.67 \times 10^{-8} (300^4-0^4)\\ 
T_1-300&=\frac{929.635}{50}\\ 
T_1&=18.59+300\\ 
T_1&=318.59\\ 
T_1&=318.6K=319K 
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 22 Consider a one-dimensional steady heat conduction
process through a solid slab of thickness [latex] 0.1 m[/latex]. The
higher temperature side A has a surface temperature
of [latex] 80^{\circ}C [/latex], and the heat transfer rate per unit area to
low temperature side B is [latex] 4.5 \; kW/m^2 [/latex]. The thermal
conductivity of the slab is [latex] 15 \; W/m.K [/latex]. The rate of
entropy generation per unit area during the heat
transfer process is ________  [latex] W/m^2.K [/latex](round off to
2 decimal places).
solution:
1D Steady heat conduction [latex]\begin{aligned} 
\frac{Q}{A} &=4.5\frac{kW}{m^2}=4500 \frac{W}{m^2}\\ 
k&=15W/mk \\ 
S_{gen}&=? \\ 
\frac{Q}{A} &= k\left [ \frac{T_1-T_2}{dx} \right ]\\ 
4500&= 15\left [ \frac{80-T_2}{0.1} \right ]\\ 
T_2 &=50^{\circ}C=323K \\ 
T_1 &=80^{\circ}C=353K \\ 
\therefore \;\; \frac{S_{gen}}{Area}&=\frac{-Q}{AT_1}+\frac{Q}{AT_2} \\ 
&=\frac{-4500}{353}+\frac{4500}{323} \\ 
S_{gen} &= 1.18\frac{W}{m^2K} 
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 23 Consider a rod of uniform thermal conductivity
whose one end [latex](x = 0)[/latex] is insulated and the other
end [latex](x = L)[/latex] is exposed to flow of air at temperature
[latex]T_\infty  [/latex] with convective heat transfer coefficient [latex]h [/latex]. The
cylindrical surface of the rod is insulated so that
the heat transfer is strictly along the axis of the rod.
The rate of internal heat generation per unit volume
inside the rod is given as [latex] \dot{q}=\cos \frac{2 \pi x}{L} [/latex] The steady state temperature at the mid-location of
the rod is given as [latex] T_A[/latex]. What will be the temperature
at the same location, if the convective heat transfer
coefficient increases to [latex] 2h[/latex]?
solution:
[latex] \dot{q}=\frac{\cos 2 \pi x}{L}[/latex] Total heat generation [latex] =Q_g=\int_{o}^{L}\dot{q}d(\text{Volume})[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned}
Q_g&=\int_{o}^{L}\dot{q}Adx\\
&=\int_{o}^{L}\left ( \frac{\cos 2\pi x}{L} \right )Adx\\
&=A\left [ \frac{\sin \left (\frac{2 \pi x}{L}  \right ) }{\frac{ 2 \pi }{L}} \right ]_{0}^{L}\\
&=\left ( \frac{L}{2 \pi} \right )A\left [  \sin \left (\frac{2 \pi x}{L} \right )- \sin (0) \right ]
\end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] Q_g=0[/latex] At steady state  [latex]Q_{stored}=0 [/latex] [latex]Q_{in}+Q_{gen}-Q_{out}=Q_{stored} [/latex] [latex]Q_{gen}=Q_{out}[/latex] [latex] 0=hA_S(T_S-T_\infty [/latex] [latex] h \text{ and } A_S[/latex] can't be zero it means [latex] T_S=T_ \infty[/latex] It indicate that [latex]T_S [/latex] is independent of heat transfer
coefficient. So it means temperature of body any where is
independent of heat transfer coefficient. So by increasing heat transfer coefficient there is no
change in the temperature at mid location.

question:
Question 24 A flat plate made of cast iron is exposed to a solar
flux of [latex]600 W/m^2[/latex]
 at an ambient temperature of  [latex]25 ^{\circ}C[/latex]. Assume that the entire solar flux is absorbed by
the plate.
Cast iron has a low temperature absorptivity of
0.21. Use Stefan-Boltzmann constant [latex]= 5.669 \times 10^{-8}
W/m^2-K^4[/latex]. Neglect all other modes of heat transfer
except radiation.
Under the aforementioned conditions, the radiation
equilibrium temperature of the plate is __________ [latex]^{\circ}C[/latex] (round off to the nearest integer).
solution:
Equilibrium Temperature [latex] =T_S=? [/latex] In this it is mentioned that entire flux is absorbed by
the plate it means for solar flux absorptivity is 1.
Kirchoff's law [latex] \alpha =\varepsilon =0.21[/latex] Surface of cast iron and surrounding fluid
temperature difference is small due to this we can
use Kirchoff's law At equilibrium condition Energy absorbed = Energy leaving [latex]\begin{aligned}
\alpha GA&=\varepsilon A\sigma (T_S^4-T_\infty ^4)\\
1 \times 600 &=0.21 \times 5.669 \times 10^{-8}(T_S^4-298^4)\\
T_S&=491.34K\\
T_S&=218.34^{\circ}C\\
T_S&=218^{\circ}C
\end{aligned} [/latex]

question:
Question 25 A tiny temperature probe is fully immersed in a
flowing fluid and is moving with zero relative
velocity with respect to the fluid. The velocity
field in the fluid is [latex]\vec{V}=2x\hat{i}+(y+3t)\hat{j}[/latex],and the
temperature field in the fluid is [latex]T=2x^2+xy+4t[/latex] where [latex]x[/latex] and [latex]y[/latex] are the spatial coordinates, and [latex]t[/latex] is
the time. The time rate of change of temperature
recorded by the probe at ([latex]x=,y=1,t=1[/latex]) is
_______.
solution:
[latex]\begin{aligned}
\frac{dT}{dt}&=? \text{ at }x=1,y=1,t=1\\
\frac{dT}{dt}&=\frac{\partial T}{\partial t}\frac{dt}{dt}+\frac{\partial T}{\partial x}\frac{dx}{dt}+\frac{\partial T}{\partial y}\frac{dy}{dt}\\
&=\frac{\partial T}{\partial t}+u\frac{\partial T}{\partial x}+v\frac{\partial T}{\partial y}\\
&=4+(2x)(4x+y)+(y+3t)(x)\\
&=4+8x^2+3xy+3xt\\
&\text{at }x=1,y=1,t=1\\
\frac{dT}{dt}&=4+8(1)^2+3(1)+3(1)\\
&=18
\end{aligned} [/latex]

question: Question 26 Ambient air flows over a heated slab having flat, top surface at [latex]y=0[/latex]. The local temperature (in Kelvin) profile within the thermal boundary layer is given by [latex]T(y)=300+200\; exp(-5y)[/latex], where [latex]y[/latex] is the distance measured from the slab surface in meter. If the thermal conductivity of air is 1.0 W/m.K and that of the slab is 100 W/m.K, then the magnitude of temperature gradient [latex]|dT/dy|[/latex] within the slab at [latex]y=0[/latex] is  ________K/m (round off to the nearest integer).
solution: Given that Temp. variation of air, [latex]T=300+200 e^{-5 y}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} K_{\text {air }} &=1 \mathrm{~W} / \mathrm{m}-\mathrm{K} \\ K_{\text {slab }} &=100 \mathrm{~W} / \mathrm{m}-\mathrm{K} \\ \left.\frac{d T}{d y}\right|_{y=0, \mathrm{slab}} &=? \end{aligned}[/latex] Applying surface energy balance at interface (y=0) heat flux leaving from slab at interface by conduction = heat flux received from air at interface by conduction [latex] \begin{aligned}  -\left.k_{\text {slab }} \frac{d T}{d y}\right|_{y=0, \text { slab }}&=-\left.k_{\text {air }} \frac{d T}{d y}\right|_{y=0, \text { air }} \\ \left.\frac{d T}{d y}\right|_{y=0, \text { air }}&=0+200 \times-5 \times 1=-1000 \mathrm{~K} / \mathrm{m} \\ -\left.100 \frac{d T}{d y}\right|_{y=0, \text { slab }}&=-1 \times-1000 \\ \left.\frac{d T}{d y}\right|_{y=0, \text { slab }}&=-10 \mathrm{~K} / \mathrm{m}\\ \text { Magnitude of }\left.\frac{d T}{d y}\right|_{y=0, \text { slab }}&=10 \mathrm{~K} / \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 27 A shell and tube heat exchanger is used as a steam condenser. Coolant water enters the tube at 300 K at a rate of 100 kg/s. The overall heat transfer coefficient is 1500 [latex]W/m^2.K[/latex], and total heat transfer area is 400 [latex]m^2[/latex]. Steam condenses at a saturation temperature of 350 K. Assume that the specific heat of coolant water is 4000 J/kg.K. The temperature of the coolant water coming out of the condenser is  _______K (round off to the nearest integer).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \mathrm{NTU}&=\frac{U A}{\left(\dot{m} c_{p}\right)_{\text {small }}}=\frac{1500 \times 400}{100 \times 4000}=1.5\\ \epsilon_{H E}&=1-e^{-N T U}=\frac{T_{c e}-T_{c i}}{T_{h i}-T_{c i}}=\frac{T_{C e}-300}{350-300}=0.7768\\ T_{c e}&=338.84 \mathrm{~K} \simeq 339 \mathrm{~K} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 28 In forced convective heat transfer, Stanton number (St), Nusselt number (Nu), Reynolds number (Re) and Prandtl number (Pr) are related as
