question: Question 29 A solid sphere of radius 10 mm is placed at the centroid of a hollow cubical enclosure of side length 30 mm. The outer surface of the sphere is denoted by 1 and the inner surface of the cube is denoted by 2. The view factor [latex]F_{22}[/latex] for radiation heat transfer is ________ (rounded off to two decimal places).

Question 30 An uninsulated cylindrical wire of radius 1.0 mm produces electric heating at the rate of 5.0 W/m. The temperature of the surface of the wire is 75 [latex]^{\circ}C[/latex] when placed in air at 25 [latex]^{\circ}C[/latex]. When the wire is coated with PVC of thickness
1.0 mm, the temperature of the surface of the wire reduces to 55 [latex]^{\circ}C[/latex]. Assume that the heat generation rate from the wire and the convective heat transfer coefficient are same for both uninsulated wire and the coated wire. The thermal conductivity of PVC is  ______W/m.K (round off to two decimal places).
solution: For uninsulated wire: Given: [latex]T_{\infty}=25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}, R_{1}=1 \mathrm{~mm}, \dot{q}_{\text {gen }}=5 \mathrm{~W} / \mathrm{m}, T_{s_{1}}=7.5^{\circ} \mathrm{C}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} q &=\dot{q}_{g e n} \times L=\frac{T_{s 1}-T_{\infty}}{\frac{1}{h \times 2 \pi R_{1} L}} \\ 5 \times L &=h \times(2 \pi \times 0.001) L \times(75-25) \\ h &=15.91 \mathrm{~W} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \mathrm{~K} \end{aligned}[/latex] For Insulated wire: [latex] R_{2}=2 \mathrm{~mm}[/latex] Heat transfer rate after insulation kept on wire, [latex] q=q_{\text {gen, wire }} \times L=5 \times L [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} q &=5 \times L=\frac{55-25}{\frac{\ln (2 / 1)}{2 \pi k_{\text {PVC }} L}+\frac{1}{15.91 \times 2 \times \pi \times 0.002 \times L}} \\ k_{P V C} &=0.1103 \mathrm{~W} / \mathrm{m}-\mathrm{K} \\ &=0.11 \mathrm{~W} / \mathrm{m}-\mathrm{K} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 31 An infinitely long pin fin, attached to an isothermal hot surface, transfers heat at a steady rate of [latex]Q_1[/latex] to the ambient air. If the thermal conductivity of the fin material is doubled, while keeping everything else constant, the rate of steady- state heat transfer from the fin becomes [latex]Q_2[/latex]. The ratio [latex]Q_2/Q_1[/latex] is
solution: Fin problem: [latex]q=\sqrt{h P k A}\left(T_{o}-T_{\infty}\right) \text { wait }[/latex] If k gets doubled q increases by [latex]\sqrt{2}[/latex] times.

question: Question 32 A hot steel spherical ball is suddenly dipped into a low temperature oil bath. Which of the following dimensionless parameters are required to determine instantaneous center temperature of the ball using a Heisler chart?
solution: Unsteady state

question:
Question 33 Water flows through a tube of 3 cm internal diameter and length 20 m, The outside surface
of the tube is heated electrically so that it is subjected to uniform heat flux circumferentially
and axially. The mean inlet and exit temperatures of the water are [latex]10^{\circ}C \; and \; 70^{\circ}C[/latex],
respectively. The mass flow rate of the water is 720 kg/h. Disregard the thermal resistance
of the tube wall. The internal heat transfer coefficient is 1697 [latex]W/m^2\cdot K[/latex]. Take specific heat
[latex]C_p[/latex] of water as 4.179 kJ/kg.K. The inner surface temperature at the exit section of the
tube is __________ [latex]^{\circ}C[/latex] (round off to one decimal place).
solution: [latex]h=1697 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \mathrm{K}[/latex] From energy balance equation, [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{Heat flux }\times \text{Area of HT}&=\dot{m}_{w} \times C_{p w}\left(T_{w}-T_{w}\right) q^{\prime \prime} \times \pi D L \\ &=\dot{m}_{w} \times C_{p w}(70-10) \\ q^{\prime \prime} &=\frac{720}{3600} \times \frac{4.179 \times 10^{3} \times 60}{\pi \times\left(\frac{3}{100}\right) \times 20} \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \\ q^{\prime \prime} &=26604.34 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] Applying Newton's law of cooling at exit [latex] \begin{aligned} q^{\prime \prime}&=h \times\left(T_{\text {tube at exit}}-T_{\text {water at exit }}\right) W / m^{2}\\ 26604.34&=1697 \times\left(T_{\text {tube at exit }}-70\right) \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \\ T_{\text {tube at exit }}&=85.67^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 34 The spectral distribution of radiation from a black body at [latex]T_1[/latex]=3000 K has a maximum
at wavelength[latex]\lambda _{max}[/latex]. The body cools down to a temperature [latex]T_2[/latex]. If the wavelength
corresponding to the maximum of the spectral distribution at [latex]T_2[/latex] is 1.2 times of the original
wavelength [latex]\lambda _{max}[/latex], then the temperature [latex]T_2[/latex] is ________ K (round off to the nearest integer).
solution: From Wien's Displacement law, [latex] \begin{aligned} \lambda_{m} T &=\text { constant } \Rightarrow \lambda_{m 1} T_{1}=\lambda_{m 2} T_{2} \\ \lambda_{m 1} \times 3000 &=1.2 \lambda_{m 1} \times T_{2} \\ T_{2} &=\left(\frac{3000}{1.2}\right) K=2500 K \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 35 In a furnace, the inner and outer sides of the brick wall ([latex]k_1 = 2.5 W/mK[/latex]) are maintained
at [latex]1100^{\circ}C[/latex] and [latex]700^{\circ}C[/latex] respectively as shown in figure. The brick wall is covered by an insulating material of thermal conductivity [latex]k_2[/latex]. The
thickness of the insulation is [latex]1/4^{th}[/latex] of the thickness of the brick wall. The outer surface
of the insulation is at [latex]200^{\circ}C[/latex]. The heat flux through the composite walls is 2500 [latex]W/m^2[/latex]. The value of [latex]k_2[/latex] is ________ W/mK (round off to 2 decimal places).
solution: Given, [latex]L_{2}=\frac{L_{1}}{4}[/latex] Assuming steady state, one-dimensional conduction heat transfer through composite  slab, Thermal circuit: [latex] \begin{array}{l} \Rightarrow \quad q=\frac{1100-700}{\frac{L_{1}}{k_{1} A}}=\frac{700-200}{\frac{L_{2}}{k_{2} A}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{400}{\frac{L_{2}}{2.5}}=\frac{500}{\frac{L_{2}}{k_{2}}}\\ \Rightarrow \quad k_{2}=0.5 \mathrm{W}-\mathrm{mK} \end{array}[/latex]

question:
Question 36 A small metal bead (radius 0.5 mm), initially at 100[latex]^{\circ}C[/latex], when placed in a stream of fluid
at 20[latex]^{\circ}C[/latex], attains a temperature of 28[latex]^{\circ}C[/latex] in 4.35 seconds. The density and specific heat
of the metal are 8500 [latex]kg/m^3[/latex] and 400 J/kgK, respectively. If the bead is considered as
lumped system, the convective heat transfer coefficient (in [latex]W/m^2 K[/latex]) between the metal
bead and the fluid stream is
solution: [latex]r=0.5 \mathrm{mm} ; c_{p}=400 \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{kgk} ; \rho=8500 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3} ; t=4.35 \mathrm{sec} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad \frac{V}{A}&=\frac{\frac{4}{3} \pi R^{3}}{4 \pi R^{2}}=\frac{R}{3} \\ \because \quad \frac{T-T_{\infty}}{T_{i}-T_{\infty}}&=e^{\frac{-h A \tau}{\rho C_{p} V}} \\ \Rightarrow \qquad \frac{28-20}{100-20}&=e^{-\left(\frac{h \cdot 3000}{0.5 \times 8500 \times 400}\right)} \times 4.35 \\ \Rightarrow \qquad h&=299.95 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \mathrm{K} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 37 In a concentric tube counter-flow heat exchanger, hot oil enters at [latex]102^{\circ}C[/latex] and leaves at
[latex]65^{\circ}C[/latex]. Cold water enters at [latex]25^{\circ}C[/latex] and leaves at [latex]42^{\circ}C[/latex]. The log mean temperature difference
(LMTD) is _______[latex]^{\circ}C[/latex] (round off to one decimal place)
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} T_{h i}&= 102^{\circ} \mathrm{C}, \quad T_{h e}=65^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \\ T_{c, i}&=25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}, \quad T_{c e}=42^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \\ \mathrm{LMTD}&=\frac{\Delta T_{1}-\Delta T_{2}}{\ln \left(\frac{\Delta T_{1}}{\Delta T_{2}}\right)} \\ &\Delta T_{1}=102^{\circ} \mathrm{C}-42^{\circ} \mathrm{C}=60^{\circ} \mathrm{C} ; \\ & \Delta T_{2}=65^{\circ} \mathrm{C}-25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}=40^{\circ} \mathrm{C}_{7} \\ \mathrm{LMTD}&=\frac{60-40}{\ln \left(\frac{60}{40}\right)}=\frac{20}{0.4054}=49.3^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 38 Hot and cold fluids enter a parallel flow double tube heat exchanger at [latex]100^{\circ}C \; and \; 15^{\circ}C[/latex], respectively. The heat capacity rates of hot and cold fluids are [latex]C_h=2000W/K[/latex] and [latex]C_c=1200W/K[/latex], respectively. If the outlet temperature of the cold fluid is [latex]45^{\circ}C[/latex], the log mean temperature difference (LMTD) of the heat exchanger is _________K (round off to two decimal places).
solution:
Given data: C_{h} = 2000 W/K Energy balance: Energy released by hot fluid = Energy received by cold fluid [latex]\begin{aligned}
 \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{h}}\left(\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{hi}}-\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{he}}\right) &=\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{c}}\left(\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{cc}}-\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{ci}}\right) \\
 2000\left(100-\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{hc}}\right)&=1200(45-15) \\
 2000 \times\left(100-\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{he}}\right)& =1200 \times 30 
 \mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{he}}=82^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \\
 \mathrm{LMTD}&=\frac{\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}}{\ln \left(\frac{\theta_{1}}{\theta_{2}}\right)} \\ &=\frac{85-37}{\ln \left(\frac{85}{37}\right)}=\frac{48}{\ln \left(\frac{85}{37}\right)} \\
 \mathrm{LMTD}&=57.71^{\circ} \mathrm{C}  \text{ or } \mathrm{K}\end{aligned} [/latex] This is logarithmic mean temperature difference either we take in [latex]^{o}C[/latex] or we take in K the final 
answer will be 57.71 K (or)[latex]^{o}C[/latex] because it is a difference.

question: Question 39 Three sets of parallel plates LM, NR and PQ are given in Figures 1, 2 and 3.The view factor [latex]F_{IJ}[/latex] is defined as the fraction of radiation leaving plate-I that is intercepted by plate-J. Assume that the values of [latex]F_{LM} \; and \; F_{NR}[/latex] are 0.8 and 0.4, respectively. The value of [latex]F_{PQ}[/latex](round off to one decimal place) is ______.
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} \mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{LM}}=\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{L}-\mathrm{a}}+\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{L}-\mathrm{b}}+\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{L}-\mathrm{c}}=0.8-\mathrm{c}\ldots(1) \\ \mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{N}-\mathrm{R}}=0.4 \end{array}[/latex] From the figure, [latex] \begin{array}{l} \mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{L}-\mathrm{a}}=\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{L}-\mathrm{c}}=\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{P}-\mathrm{e}}(\text { similar }) \\ \mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{L}-\mathrm{b}}=\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{N}-\mathrm{R}}(\text { similar }) \end{array}[/latex] From equation (1) [latex] \begin{array}{l} \mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{L}-\mathrm{a}}+\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{L}-\mathrm{b}}+\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{L}-\mathrm{c}}=0.8 \\ 2 \times \mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{L}-\mathrm{a}}+\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{N}-\mathrm{R}}=0.8 \\ \mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{L}-\mathrm{a}}=\frac{0.8-0.4}{2}=0.2 \end{array}[/latex] From the fig -3 [latex] \begin{aligned} \mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{P}-\mathrm{Q}}&=\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{P}-\mathrm{d}}+\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{P}-\mathrm{e}} =\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{N}-\mathrm{R}}+\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{L}-\mathrm{a}} \\ (\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{P}-\mathrm{d}}&=\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{N}-\mathrm{R}} \text{ and } \mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{P}-\mathrm{e}}=\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{L}-\mathrm{a}}(\text { due to similarity })) \\ &=0.4+0.2\\ F_{P-Q}&=0.6 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 40 A thin vertical flat plate of height L, and infinite width perpendicular to the plane of the figure, is losing heat to the surroundings by natural convection. The temperatures of theplate and the surroundings, and the properties of the surrounding fluid, are constant. The relationship between the average Nusselt and Rayleigh numbers is given as [latex]Nu=KRa^{1/4}[/latex], where K is a constant. The length scales for Nusselt and Rayleigh numbers are the height of the plate. The height of the plate is increased to 16L keeping all other factors constant. If the average heat transfer coefficient for the first plate is [latex]h_1[/latex] and that for the second plate is [latex]h_2[/latex], the value of the ratio [latex]h_1/h_2[/latex] is _______
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} \mathrm{Nu}=\mathrm{K}(\mathrm{Ra})^{1 / 4} \\ \mathrm{Nu}=\mathrm{K}(\mathrm{Gr} \cdot \mathrm{Pr})^{1 / 4} \\ \mathrm{Nu} \propto(\mathrm{Gr})^{1 / 4} \\ \mathrm{Nu} \propto\left(\frac{\mathrm{g} \beta \Delta \mathrm{TL}^{3}}{v^{2}}\right)^{1 / 4}\\ \mathrm{Nu} \propto \mathrm{L}^{3 / 4} \\ \frac{\mathrm{h.L}}{\mathrm{K}} \propto \mathrm{L}^{3 / 4} \\ \mathrm{h} \propto \mathrm{L}^{3 / 4-1} \\ \mathrm{h} \propto \mathrm{L}^{-1 / 4} \\ \frac{\mathrm{h}_{1}}{\mathrm{h}_{2}}=\left(\frac{\mathrm{L}_{1}}{\mathrm{L}_{2}}\right)^{-1 / 4}=\left(\frac{\mathrm{L}}{16 \mathrm{L}}\right)^{-1 / 4}=\left(\frac{1}{16}\right)^{-1 / 4} \\ \frac{\mathrm{h}_{1}}{\mathrm{h}_{2}}=2 \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 41 One-dimensional  steady  state  heat  conduction  takes  place  through  a  solid  whose cross-sectional area varies linearly in the direction of heat transfer. Assume there is no heat generation in the solid and the thermal conductivity of the material is constant and independent of temperature. The temperature distribution in the solid is
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{c} \text { Area }(\mathrm{A}) \propto \mathrm{x} \\ \mathrm{A}=\mathrm{c} \mathrm{x} \end{array}[/latex] According to Fourier's law of heat conduction [latex] \mathrm{Q}=-\mathrm{k} \mathrm{A} \frac{\mathrm{d} \mathrm{T}}{\mathrm{d} \mathrm{x}}[/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{l} \mathrm{Q}=-\mathrm{k} \cdot \mathrm{c} \mathrm{x} \frac{\mathrm{d} \mathrm{T}}{\mathrm{d} \mathrm{x}} \\ \mathrm{Q} \frac{\mathrm{d} \mathrm{x}}{\mathrm{x}}=-\mathrm{k} \mathrm{c} \mathrm{d} \mathrm{T} \\ \int \mathrm{d} \mathrm{T}=-\frac{\mathrm{Q}}{\mathrm{k} \mathrm{c}} \int \frac{\mathrm{d} \mathrm{x}}{\mathrm{x}} \\ \mathrm{T}=-\frac{\mathrm{Q}}{\mathrm{k}_{\mathrm{r}}} \ln \mathrm{x}+\mathrm{c}_{1} \end{array}[/latex] Temperature distribution is logarithmic. (or) In hollow cylinder, area is linearly proportional to radius. [latex] A = 2\pi rL[/latex] Temperature profile is logarithmic in case of hollow cylinder with no heat generation.

question: Question 42 Sphere-1 with a diameter of 0.1 m is completely enclosed by another sphere-2 of diameter 0.4 m. The view factor [latex]F_{12}[/latex] is
solution: Given data: [latex] \mathrm{d}_{1}=0.1 \mathrm{m} [/latex] [latex] \mathrm{d}_{2}=0.4 \mathrm{m} [/latex] [latex] \mathrm{F}_{1-1}=0 [/latex] (from the geometry) From the additive rule [latex] \mathrm{F}_{1-1}+\mathrm{F}_{1-2}=1 [/latex] [latex] \mathrm{F}_{1-2}=1[/latex]

question: Question 43 Three slabs are joined together as shown in the figure. There is no thermal contact resistance at the interfaces. The center slab experiences a non-uniform internal heat generation with an average value equal to 10000 [latex]Wm^{-3}[/latex], while the left and right slabs have no internal heat generation. All slabs have thickness equal to 1 m and thermal conductivity of each slab is equal to 5 [latex]Wm^{-1}K^{-1}[/latex]. The two extreme faces are exposed to fluid with heat transfer coefficient 100 [latex]Wm^{-2}K^{-1}[/latex] and bulk temperature [latex]30^{\circ}C[/latex] as shown. The heat transfer in the slabs is assumed to be one dimensional and steady, and all properties are constant. If the left extreme face temperature [latex]T_1[/latex] is  measured  to  be [latex]100^{\circ}C[/latex],  the  right  extreme  face  temperature [latex]T_2[/latex] is_________[latex]^{\circ}C[/latex].
solution: Energy balance : Heat generated in middle slab = heat loss by slab (1) and (3) to the surrounding [latex] \dot{\mathrm{q}} \times \text { volume }=\frac{\left(\mathrm{T}_{1}-30\right)}{\frac{1}{\mathrm{hA}}}+\frac{\left(\mathrm{T}_{2}-30\right)}{\frac{1}{\mathrm{hA}}}[/latex] [latex] 10000 \times \mathrm{A} \times 1=\mathrm{hA}\left(\mathrm{T}_{1}-30+\mathrm{T}_{2}-30\right) [/latex] [latex] 1000 \times 1=100\left(100+\mathrm{T}_{2}-60\right)[/latex] [latex] \mathrm{T}_{2}=60^{\circ} \mathrm{C}[/latex]

question: Question 44 A slender rod of length L, diameter d ([latex]L \gt \gt d[/latex]) and thermal conductivity [latex]k_1[/latex] is joined with another rod of identical dimensions, but of thermal conductivity [latex]k_2[/latex], to form a composite cylindrical rod of length 2L. The heat transfer in radial direction and contact resistance are negligible. The effective thermal conductivity of the composite rod is
solution: Area is constant in the direction of heat flow. (similar like slab) Thermal circuit : [latex] \begin{array}{l} \text { Heat transfer rate, }(Q)=\frac{T_{1}-T_{3}}{\frac{L}{k_{1} A}+\frac{L}{k_{2} A}}=\frac{T_{1}-T_{3}}{\frac{2 L}{k_{e q} A}} \\ \frac{L}{k_{1} A}+\frac{L}{k_{2} A}=\frac{2 L}{k_{e q} A} \\ \frac{2}{k_{e q}}=\frac{1}{k_{1}}+\frac{1}{k_{2}} \\ k_{e q}=\frac{2 k_{1} k_{2}}{k_{1}+k_{2}} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 45 For a hydrodynamically and thermally fully developed laminar flow through a circular pipe of constant cross-section, the Nusselt number at constant wall heat flux ([latex]Nu_q[/latex]) and that at constant wall temperature ([latex]Nu_T[/latex]) are related as
solution: For laminar flow through circular tube: [latex] \mathrm{Nu}_{\mathrm{q}}=4.36 [/latex] (For constant heat flux) [latex] \mathrm{Nu}_{\mathrm{T}}=3.66 [/latex] (For constant wall temperature) [latex] \mathrm{Nu}_{\mathrm{q}} \gt \mathrm{Nu}_{\mathrm{T}} [/latex]

question:
Question 46 Steam in the condenser of a thermal power plant is to be condensed at a temperature of
[latex]30^{\circ}C[/latex] with cooling water which enters the tubes of the condenser at [latex]14^{\circ}C[/latex] and exits at [latex]22^{\circ}C[/latex]. The total surface area of the tubes is 50 [latex]m^{2}[/latex], and the overall heat transfer coefficient
is 2000 W/[latex]m^{2}[/latex] K. The heat transfer (in MW) to the condenser is ______ (correct to two
decimal places).
solution: Since steam is condensing, the temperature of hot fluid remains constant. [latex] \therefore[/latex] Temperature profiles of hot and cold fluids are [latex] \therefore (\mathrm{LMTD}) of H E=\frac{\Delta T_{i}-\Delta T_{e}}{\ln \frac{\Delta T_{i}}{\Delta T_{e}}}=\frac{16-8}{\ln \left(\frac{16}{8}\right)}=11.54^{\circ} \mathrm{C} [/latex] Total heat transfer rate between steam [latex] \begin{aligned} \mathrm{C.W.} &=Q=U A \mathrm{LMTD} \mathrm{W} \\ &=2000 \times 50 \times 11.54 \\ &=11.54 \times 10^{5} \mathrm{W} \\ &=1.154 \mathrm{MW} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 47 A 0.2 m thick infinite black plate having a thermal conductivity of 3.96 W/m-K is exposed
to two infinite black surfaces at 300 K and 400 K as shown in the figure. At steady state,
the surface temperature of the plate facing the cold side is 350 K. The value of Stefan-
Boltzmann constant, [latex]\sigma[/latex] , is [latex]5.67 \times 10^{-8} \: W/m^{2}\: K^{4}[/latex] Assuming 1-D heat conduction, the magnitude of heat flux through the plate (in W/[latex]m^{2}[/latex]) is ________ (correct to two decimal places).
solution:
Under steady state condition, all rate of heat transfer i.e. from surface at 400 K to black
plate (via radiation), inside black plate (via conduction) and from black plate to surface
at 300 K (via radiation) are equal. So, heat flux through wall= flux from wall to surface at 300 K [latex]=\frac{\sigma\left(350^{4}-300^{4}\right)}{\frac{1}{1}+\frac{1}{1}-1}=391.612 \text { watt/m }^{2}[/latex]

question: Question 48 An engine operates on the reversible cycle as shown in the figure. The work output from the engine (in kJ/cycle) is ______ (correct to two decimal places).
solution: Work output = Area endosed on pr diagram [latex] \begin{array}{l} =\frac{1}{2}(2.5-2) \times(650-400) \\ =62.5(\mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{cycle}) \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 49 The peak wavelength of radiation emitted by a black body at a temperature of 2000 K is 1.45 [latex]\mu[/latex]m. If the peak wavelength of emitted radiation changes to 2.90 [latex]\mu[/latex]m, then the temperature (in K) of the black body is
solution: From Wein's displacement law For black body, [latex]\begin{aligned} \lambda_{M} T &=\text { constant } \\ \lambda_{M 1} T_{1} &=\lambda_{M 2} T_{2} \\ 1.45 \times 2000 &=\lambda_{M 2} T_{2}=2.90 \times T_{2} \\ \therefore \quad T_{2} &=\left(\frac{1.45}{2.90} \times 2000\right)=1000 \mathrm{K} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 50 A plane slab of thickness L and thermal conductivity k is heated with a fluid on one side (P), and the other side (Q) is maintained at a constant temperature, [latex]T_{Q}[/latex]  of [latex]25^{\circ}C[/latex] , as shown in the figure. The fluid is at [latex]45^{\circ}C[/latex]  and the surface heat transfer coefficient, h, is [latex]10 W/m^{2}K[/latex]  . The steady state temperature, [latex]T_{P}[/latex] , (in [latex]^{\circ}C[/latex] ) of the side which is exposed to the fluid is _______ (correct to two decimal places).
solution: Assuming steady state conditions Thermal circuit [latex]\begin{aligned} q &=\text { Rate of heat transfer }\\ &=\frac{45-T_{P}}{1 / h A}\\ &=\frac{T_{p}-25}{L / k A} \\ \Rightarrow\qquad \frac{45-T_{P}}{\left(\frac{1}{10}\right)} &=\frac{T_{P}-25}{\frac{0.2}{2.5}} \\ T_{p} &=33.889^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 51 A metal ball of diameter 60mm is initially at [latex]220\, ^{\circ}C[/latex]. The ball is suddenly cooled by an air jet of [latex]20\, ^{\circ}C[/latex]. The heat transfer coeffient is [latex]200 \: W/m^{2}[/latex]. The specific heat,thermal  conductivity and density of the metall ball are [latex]400\:J/kg\! \cdot\! K[/latex] ,[latex]400\:W/m\! \cdot\! K[/latex]  and [latex]9000\,kg/m^{3}[/latex], The ball temperature (in [latex]^{\circ}C[/latex]) after 90 seconds will be approximately.
solution: [latex] \begin{aligned} c_{p} &=400 \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{kgK} \\ k &=400 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{mK} \\ \rho &=9000 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ \text { Time }(\tau) &=90 \mathrm{sec} \end{aligned}[/latex] since K being high and size of ball being small, lumped heat analysis is valid. [latex] \begin{aligned} \Rightarrow \quad e^{\left(\frac{h A}{\rho V C_{p}}\right)^{\tau}}&=\frac{T_{i}-T_{\infty}}{T-T_{\infty}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad\left(\frac{h_{A}}{\rho v c_{p}}\right) \tau&=\ln \left(\frac{T_{i}-T_{\infty}}{T-T \infty}\right) \\ \text{Put }\quad \frac{A}{V}&=\frac{3}{R}=\frac{3}{\left(\frac{30}{1000}\right)} \\ \left(\frac{h A}{\rho v c_{p}}\right) \tau &=\left(200 \times \frac{3}{0.03} \times \frac{1}{9000} \times \frac{1}{400}\right) \times 90 \\ &=0.5 \\ \frac{220-20}{T-20} &=e^{0.5}=1.6487 \\ T &=141.3^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 52 In a counter-flow heat exchanger, water is heated at the rate of 1.5kg/s from [latex]40\,^{\circ} C[/latex]  to [latex]80\,^{\circ} C[/latex] by an oil entering at [latex]120\,^{\circ} C[/latex] and leaving at [latex]60\,^{\circ} C[/latex].  The specific heat of water and oil are [latex]4.2\:kJ/kg \! \cdot\!K[/latex]  and [latex]2\:kJ/kg \! \cdot\!K[/latex], respectively. The overall heat transfer coefficient is [latex]400\, W/m^{2} \cdot K[/latex]  The required heat transfer surface area (in [latex]m^{2}[/latex] ) is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \Delta T_{i} &=120-80=40^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \\ \Delta T_{e} &=60-40=20^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \\ (L M T D) \text { Counterflow }&=\frac{\Delta T_{i}-\Delta T_{e}}{\ln \frac{\Delta T_{i}}{\Delta T_{e}}} =28.86^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \\ &=\frac{40-20}{\ln \frac{40}{20}} = 28.86^{o}\mathrm{C}\\ Q &=\dot{m}_{C} c_{p_{c}}\left(T_{c e}-T_{c i}\right) \\ &=1.5 \times 4.2 \times 10^{3}(80-40) \mathrm{watt} \\ Q &=252000 \mathrm{W} \\ Q &=U A \Delta T_{m} \\ A &=\frac{Q}{U \Delta T_{m}}=\frac{1.5 \times 4.2 \times 10^{3} \times 40}{400 \times 28.86} \\ &=21.83 \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 53 The emissive power of a blackbody is P. If its absolute temperature is doubled, the emissive power becomes
solution: [latex]E_{b} \propto T^{4} [/latex](Stefan Boltzmann Law of Radiation) [latex] \frac{E_{b_{2}}}{E_{b_{1}}}=\left(\frac{2 T}{T}\right)^{4} \Rightarrow E_{b_{2}}=16 P[/latex]

question: Question 54 The heat loss from a fin in 6W. The effectiveness and efficiency of the fin are 3 and 0.75, respectively. The heat loss (in W) from the fin, keeping the entire fin surface at base temperature, is ________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} q_{\text {actual }} \text { from fin } &=6 \text { watt } \\ \eta_{\text {fin }} &=\frac{q_{\text {actual }}}{q_{\text {max possible }}} \text { i.e. when entire } \end{aligned}[/latex] fin at base temperature [latex] \therefore [/latex]q from fin if entire fin at base temp [latex] =\frac{q_{\text {act }}}{0.75}=\frac{6}{0.75}=8 \text { watt }[/latex]

question: Question 55 Heat is generated uniformly in a long solid cylindrical rod (diameter = 10mm) at the rate of [latex]4\,\times\,10^{7}[/latex]  W/[latex]m^{3}[/latex]. The thermal conductivity of the rod material is 25W/m.K. Under steady state conditions, the temperature difference between the centre and the surface of the rod is _________ [latex]^{\circ}C[/latex].
solution: [latex] \begin{aligned} T_{0}&= \text{ Temp. of cylinder at the axis}\\ T_{S} &=\text { Surface Temp. of Rod (cylindel) } \\ T_{O}-T_{S} &=\frac{\dot{q}}{4 k} R^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \dot{q}[/latex] uniform heat generation rate per unit volumne [latex] \left(w / m^{3}\right) [/latex] [latex] T_{0}-T_{S}=\frac{4 \times 10^{7}}{4 \times 25} \times\left(\frac{5}{1000}\right)^{2}=10^{\circ} \mathrm{C}[/latex]

question: Question 56 Two black surfaces, AB and BC, of lengths 5m and 6m, respectively, are oriented as shown. Both surfaces extend infinitely into the third dimension. Given that view factor [latex]F_{12}=0.5[/latex],[latex]T_{1}=800K[/latex],[latex]T_{2}=600K[/latex] , [latex]T_{surrounding} =300K[/latex], and Stefan Boltzmann constant, [latex]\sigma =5.67\,\times\,10^{-8}W/(m^{2}K^{4})[/latex], the heat transfer rate from Surface 2 to the surrounding environment is ____________ kW.
solution: Marks to All as per IIT official Answer [latex]F_{12} =0.5[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} T_{1} &=800 \mathrm{K} \\ T_{2} &=600 \mathrm{K} \\ T_{\text {surounding }} &=300 \mathrm{K} \end{aligned}[/latex] Let (3) denote the surrounding environment (Assume unit width perpendicular to plane of Fig.) From summation rule: [latex] \begin{aligned} F_{21}+F_{\beta 2}^{0}+F_{23} &=1 \\ A_{1} F_{12} &=A_{2} F_{21}=6 \times 1 \times 0.5 \\ &=(5 \times 1) \times F_{21} \\ F_{21} &=\frac{6 \times 0.5}{5}=0.6\\ \therefore \quad F_{23}&=1-F_{21}=0.4 \end{aligned}[/latex] since surrounding environment being large, No surface has a surface resistance. Heat transfer rate from (2) and (3)[latex]=\frac{E_{b_{2}}-E_{b_{3}}}{\frac{1}{A_{2} F_{23}}} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\frac{\sigma\left(T_{2}^{4}-T_{3}^{4}\right)}{1} \\ &=\frac{5.67 \times 10^{-8}\left(600^{4}-300^{4}\right)}{A_{2} F_{23}} \text { watt/metre }\\ &=13.778 \mathrm{kW} / \mathrm{metre} \\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Assume that heat exchange is per unit width perpendicular to plane of figure

question: Question 57 Saturated steam at [latex]100^{\circ}[/latex]C condenses  on the outside of a tube.cold fluid enters the tube at  [latex]20^{\circ}[/latex]C and exits at [latex]50^{\circ}[/latex]C the value of the log mean Temperature Difference (LMTD) is _________[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C.
solution: Temperature profiles are [latex] \begin{aligned} \Delta T_{i}=100-20=80^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \\ \Delta T_{e}=100-50=50^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \end{aligned}[/latex] (LMTD) (parallel or counter HE) [latex] \begin{aligned} =\frac{\Delta T_{i}-\Delta T_{e}}{\ln \frac{\Delta T_{i}}{\Delta T_{e}}}=\frac{80-50}{\ln \frac{80}{50}} \\ =63.82^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 58 A cylindrical steel rod, 0.01 m in diameter and 0.2 m in length is first heated to [latex]750^{\circ}C[/latex]  and then immersed in a water bath at [latex]100^{\circ}C[/latex] .  The heat transfer coefficient is 250 W/[latex]m^{2}[/latex]-K. The density, specific heat and thermal conductivity of steel are [latex]\rho = 7801 kg/m^{3}[/latex], c = 473 J/kg-K, and  k = 43 W/m-K, respectively.  The time required for the rod to reach [latex]300^{\circ}C[/latex]  is ________  seconds.
solution: Given data: [latex] \mathrm{D}=0.01 \mathrm{m} ; \quad L=0.2 \mathrm{m} ; \quad T_{i}=750^{\circ} \mathrm{C} [/latex] [latex] T_{\infty}=100^{\circ} \mathrm{C} ; \quad h=250 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \mathrm{K} ; \quad \rho=7801 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3} [/latex] [latex] \mathrm{c}=473 \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{kgK} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{T-T_{\infty}}{T_{i}-T_{\infty}}&=\mathrm{e}^{-\frac{h A t}{\rho V c}}\\\text{ Where }\quad \frac{V}{A}&=\frac{\pi D^{2} L}{4 \times \pi D L}=\frac{D}{4}=\frac{0.01}{4} \\ &=2.5 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{m} \\ \therefore \frac{300-100}{750-100}&=e^{\frac{-250 \times t}{7801 \times 2.5 \times 10^{-3} \times 473}} \\ \frac{200}{650}&=e^{-0.0271 t} \\ 0.30769&=e^{-0.0271 t}\end{aligned}[/latex] Taking [latex]  \log _{e} [/latex] both sides, we get [latex]\begin{aligned}  \log _{e} 0.30769&=-0.0271 t \log _{e} e \\ &\qquad\left(\because \log _{\theta} e=1\right) \\ t&=\frac{1.1786}{0.027}=43.65 \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 59 Two large parallel plates having a gap of 10 mm in between them are maintained at temperatures  T1 = 1000 K and T2 = 400 K. Given emissivity values, [latex]\varepsilon{1}=0.5[/latex] ,  [latex]\varepsilon_{2}=0.25[/latex]  and Stefan-Boltzmann constant [latex]\sigma= 5.67 \times 10^{-8} W/m^{2}-K^{4}[/latex], the heat transfer between the plates (in kW/[latex]m^{2}[/latex]) is __________ _________
solution: [latex] \begin{aligned} Q &=\frac{\sigma\left[T_{1}^{4}-T_{2}^{4}\right]}{\frac{1}{\epsilon_{1}}+\frac{1}{\epsilon_{2}}-1}=\frac{5.67 \times 10^{-8} \times\left(1000^{4}-400^{4}\right)}{\frac{1}{0.5}+\frac{1}{0.25}-1} \\ &=11049.7 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m}^{2}=11.05 \mathrm{kW} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 60 For a heat exchanger, [latex]\Delta T_{max}[/latex] is the maximum temperature difference and [latex]\Delta T_{min}[/latex] is the minimum temperature difference between the two fluids. LMTD is the log mean temperature difference. [latex]C_{min}[/latex] and[latex]C_{max}[/latex] are the minimum and the maximum heat capacity rates. The maximum possible heat transfer ([latex]Q_{max}[/latex]) between the two fluids is
solution: Maximum heat transfer possible [latex] =C_{\min } \times(\Delta T)_{\max }[/latex]

question: Question 61 Grashof number signifies the ratio of
solution: Grashof number is ratio of buoyancy force to viscous force.

options.D: inertia force to surface tension force

question: Question 62 Steady one-dimensional heat conduction takes place across the faces 1 and 3 of a composite slab consisting of slabs A and B in perfect contact as shown in the figure, where [latex]k_{A},k_{B}[/latex] denote the respective thermal conductivities. Using the data as given in the figure, the interface temperature  T2 (in [latex]^{\circ}C[/latex]) is __________
solution: At steady state [latex] \begin{aligned} Q_{A} &=Q_{B} \\ \frac{k_{A}\left[T_{1}-T_{2}\right] A}{L_{1}} &=\frac{k_{B}\left[T_{2}-T_{3}\right] A}{L_{2}} \\ \frac{20 \times\left[130-T_{2}\right]}{0.1} &=\frac{100 \times\left[T_{2}-30\right]}{0.3} \\ 3\left[130-T_{2}\right] &=5 T_{2}-150 \\ 390-3 T_{2} &=5 T_{2}-150 \\ 540 &=8 T_{2} \\ T_{2} &=67.5^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 63 Two cylindrical shafts A and B at the same initial temperature are simultaneously placed in a furnace. The surfaces of the shafts remain at the furnace gas temperature at all times after they are introduced into the furnace. The temperature variation in the axial direction of the shafts can be assumed to be negligible. The data related to shafts A and B is given in the following Table. The temperature at the centerline of the shaft A reaches [latex]400^{\circ}[/latex] C after two hours. The time required (in hours) for the centerline of the shaft B to attain the temperature of [latex]400^{\circ}[/latex] C is _______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} T_{(r, t)} &=T_{0}+\left(T_{\infty}-T_{0}\right) \operatorname{erf}(z) \\ \frac{T_{(r, t)}-T_{0}}{T_{\infty}-T_{0}} &=\operatorname{erf}(z) \\ \frac{T_{(r, t)}-T_{0}}{T_{\infty}-T_{0}} &=\operatorname{erf}(z) \end{aligned}[/latex] For shaft A [latex]\quad \frac{T_{0.2, t}-T_{i}}{400-T_{i}} [/latex] For shaft B [latex]\quad \frac{T_{0.05, t}-T_{i}}{400-T_{i}} [/latex] Hence error function of both shafts will be same. [latex] \therefore \qquad z_{A}=z_{B}[/latex][latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{\Gamma_{A}}{2 \sqrt{\alpha_{A} t_{A}}} &=\frac{T_{B}}{2 \sqrt{\alpha_{B} t_{B}}} \\ \frac{\Gamma_{A}}{\sqrt{\alpha_{A} t_{A}}} &=\frac{\Gamma_{B}}{\sqrt{\alpha_{B} t_{B}}} \\ \frac{\Gamma_{A}^{2}}{\alpha_{A} t_{A}} &=\frac{r_{B}^{2}}{\alpha_{B} t_{B}} \\ t_{B} &=\left(\frac{r_{B}}{r_{A}}\right)^{2} \times \frac{\alpha_{A}}{\alpha_{B}} \times t_{A} \\ \alpha_{A} &=\frac{k}{\rho c_{p}}=\frac{40}{2 \times 10^{6}}=\frac{20}{10^{6}} \mathrm{m}^{2} / \mathrm{s} \\ \alpha_{B} &=\frac{k}{\rho c_{p}}=\frac{20}{2 \times 10^{7}}=\frac{1}{10^{6}} \mathrm{m}^{2} / \mathrm{s} \\ t_{B} &=\left(\frac{r_{B}}{r_{A}}\right)^{2} \times \frac{\alpha_{A}}{\alpha_{B}} \times t_{A} \\ &=\left(\frac{0.1}{0.4}\right)^{2} \times \frac{20}{10^{6} \times \frac{1}{10^{6}}} \times 2 \\ &=\frac{1}{16} \times 20 \times 2=2.5 \mathrm{hrs} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 64 Consider a parallel-flow heat exchanger with area [latex]A_{p}[/latex]  and a counter-flow heat exchanger with area [latex]A_{c}[/latex]. In both the heat exchangers, the hot stream flowing at 1 kg/s cools from [latex]80^{\circ}[/latex]C to [latex]50^{\circ}[/latex]C .  For the
cold stream in both the heat exchangers, the flow rate and the inlet temperature are 2 kg/s and [latex]10^{\circ}[/latex]C , respectively. The hot and cold streams in both the heat exchangers are of the same fluid.
Also, both the heat exchangers have the same overall heat transfer coefficient. The ratio  [latex]A_{c}[/latex]/ [latex]A_{p}[/latex] is _________
solution:
Parallel flow [latex]A_{p} =[/latex] Area of parallel flow heat exchanger Counter flow [latex]A_{c}= [/latex] Area of counter flow heat exchanger Heat lost by hot stream in both heat exchanger [latex] \begin{aligned} &=m c\left[T_{h i}-T_{h o}\right] \\ &=1 \times c \times\left[T_{h i}-T_{h o}\right] \\ &=1 \times c \times[80-50]=30 \mathrm{ckW} \end{aligned}[/latex] Heat gained by cold stream in both exchange [latex]\begin{aligned} &=m c\left[T_{co}-T_{c i}\right] \\ &=2 \times c\left[T_{c o}-10\right] \end{aligned}[/latex] Heat lost by hot stream = Heat gain by cool stream [latex]\begin{aligned}
30c &=2c(T_\infty -10) \\ 
 T_\infty &= \frac{30}{2}+10\\ 
 &=15+10=25^{\circ} C\\ 
 A_P, LMTD&= \frac{\Delta T_i-\Delta T_e}{ln(\Delta T_i/\Delta T_e)}\\ 
 &= \frac{70-25}{ln(70/25)}=43.705^{\circ} C\\ 
 Q_H&=UA_P 43.705 \\ 
 A_C, LMTD&= \frac{\Delta T_i-\Delta T_e}{ln(\Delta T_i/\Delta T_e)}\\ 
 &= \frac{55-40}{ln(55/40)}=47.103^{\circ} C\\ 
 Q_H&=UA_C 47.103 \\
\therefore \; UA_P 43.705 &=UA_C 47.103\\
\frac{43.705}{47.103}&=\frac{A_C}{A_P}=0.927
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 65 Consider the radiation heat exchange inside an annulus between two very long concentric cylinders. The radius of the outer cylinder is [latex]R_{0}[/latex]  and that of the inner cylinder is [latex]R_{i}[/latex] . The radiation view factor of the outer cylinder onto itself is
solution: To find: Radiation view factor of the outer cylinder onto itself. Hence [latex] F_{11} [/latex] is required. [latex] \begin{aligned} \Rightarrow A_{1} F_{12}&=A_{2} F_{21} \qquad[\text { Reciprosity }]\\ F_{11}+F_{12}&=1 \qquad \text { [Summation] }\\ F_{21}+F_{22}&=1\\ \therefore \quad F_{11}&=1-F_{12} \\ F_{22}&=0  \text { [No radiation leaving }\\ &\text{surface 2 reaches back to 2]}\\ \therefore \quad F_{21} &=1 \\ F_{12} &=\frac{A_{2}}{A_{1}} \times F_{21}=\frac{A_{2}}{A_{1}} \times 1 \\ &=\frac{2 \pi R_{i} L}{2 \pi R_{0} L} \times 1=\frac{R_{i}}{R_{0}} \\ F_{11} &=1-F_{12}=1-\frac{R_{i}}{R_{0}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 66 A hollow cylinder has length L, inner radius [latex]r_{1}[/latex], outer radius [latex]r_{2}[/latex], and thermal conductivity k. The thermal resistance of the cylinder for radial conduction is
solution: [latex]Q=\frac{\Delta T}{\text { Thermal resistance }} [/latex] Thermal resistance [latex]=\int_{t_{1}}^{t_{2}} \frac{L}{k A} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \quad&=\int_{t_{1}}^{r_{2}} \frac{d r}{k \times 2 \pi r l} \\ \quad&=\frac{1}{2 \pi / k} \int_{r_{1}}^{r_{2}} \frac{d r}{r} \\ \quad&=\frac{1}{2 \pi l k}[\ln r]_{r_{1}}^{r_{2}} \\ \quad&=\frac{1}{2 \pi l k} \ln \frac{r_{2}}{r_{1}} \\ \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 67 A fluid (Prandtl number, Pr = 1) at 500 K flows over a flat plate of 1.5 m length, maintained at 300 K. The velocity of the fluid is 10 m/s. Assuming kinematic viscosity, v=30 [latex]\times 10^{-6}m^{2}/s[/latex],  the thermal boundary layer thickness (in mm) at 0.5 m from the leading edge is __________
solution: Given [latex] \begin{aligned} P r &=1 \\ T_{\infty} &=500 \mathrm{K} \\ \text { Length } &=1.5 \mathrm{m} \\ T_{\text {plate }} &=300 \mathrm{K} \\ U_{\infty} &=10 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ v &=30 \times 10^{-6} \mathrm{m}^{2} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex] Thermal boundary layer at [latex]0.5 \mathrm{m}[/latex] from leadra edge [latex] =\delta_{t} [/latex] [latex] \text{Re}_{x=0.5}=\frac{U x}{v}=\frac{10 \times 0.5}{30 \times 10^{-6}}=166,666.67 [/latex] since [latex] \text{Re}_{x=0.5} \lt 5 \times 10^{5}[/latex]. Hence flow is laminar [latex] \begin{aligned}\therefore \quad \delta &=\frac{5 x}{\sqrt{\text{Re}_{x}}} \\ &=\frac{5 \times 0.5}{\sqrt{166,666.67}} \\ &=6.1237 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{m} \\ \frac{\delta_{t}}{\delta} &=\left(P_{f}\right)^{1 / 3} \\ \delta_{t} &=(1)^{1 / 3} \times \delta \\ &=1 \times 6.1237 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{m} \\ &=6.1237 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 68 An infinitely long furnace of 0.5 m x 0. 4 m cross-section is shown in the figure below. Consider all surfaces of the furnace to be black. The top and bottom walls are maintained at temperature [latex]T_{1}=T_{3}=927^{\circ}C[/latex]  while the side walls are at temperature [latex]T_{2}=T_{4}=527^{\circ}C[/latex] . The view factor, [latex]F_{1-2}[/latex]  is 0.26. The net radiation heat loss or gain on side 1 is_________ W/m. Stefan-Boltzmann constant = [latex]5.67\times10 ^{-8}W/m^{2}-k^{4}[/latex]
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Given: } F_{12}&=0.26 \\ F_{12}=F_{14}&=0.26 \qquad [symmetry]\\ \text{Given}\quad \sigma&=5.67 \times 10^{-8} \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \mathrm{K}^{4} \end{aligned}[/latex] side (1) and (3) will not exchange and heat being at same temp. side (2) and (4) will not exchange any heat being at same temp. Hence side (1) and side (2) and side (1) and side (4) will exchange heat [latex] \begin{aligned} Q_{1-2} &=A_{1} F_{12} \sigma\left[T_{1}^{4}-T_{2}^{4}\right] \\ &=0.5 \times 0.26 \times 5.67 \times 10^{-8} x \\ &=12265.34 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m} \\ Q_{1-4} &=0.5 \times 0.26 \times 5.67 \times 10^{-8} \mathrm{x} \\ &=12265.34 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m} \\ Q_{\text {net }} &=Q_{1-2}+Q_{1-4}=12265.34+\\ &=24530.68 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 69 A steel ball of 10 mm diameter at 1000 K is required to be cooled to 350 K by immersing it in a water environment at 300 K. The convective heat transfer coefficient is 1000 [latex]W/m^{2}-K[/latex]  Thermal conductivity of steel is 40 W/m-K. The time constant for the cooling process [latex]\tau[/latex]  is 16 s. The time required (in s) to reach the final temperature is __________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Diameter of ball } &=10 \mathrm{mm} \\ T_{\text {initial }} &=1000 \mathrm{K} \\ T_{\text {final }} &=350 \mathrm{K} \\ T_{\infty} &=300 \mathrm{K} \\ h &=1000 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \mathrm{K} \\ k &=40 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{mK} \\ \text { Time constant } &=16 \mathrm{s} \\ \text { Time required } &=t \mathrm{s} \\ \frac{T-T_{\infty}}{T_{i}-T_{\infty}} &=e^{-\frac{h A t}{\rho v c}} \\ &=16 \mathrm{second} \\ \text { But } \quad \frac{\rho v c}{h A} &=\text { Time constant } \\ \frac{350-300}{1000-300} &=e^{-\frac{1}{16}} \times t \\ 0.07143 &=e^{-t/ 16} \end{aligned}[/latex] Taking [latex] \log _{e} [/latex] both sides, we get [latex] \begin{aligned} \log _{e} 0.07143 &=\frac{-t}{16} \log _{e} e & &\left(\because \log _{e} e=1\right) \\ -2.639 &= \frac{-t}{16} \\ \text{or}\quad t &=42.23 \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 70 A plastic sleeve of outer radius [latex]r_{0}=1mm[/latex] covers a wire (radius r = 0.5 mm) carrying electric current. Thermal conductivity of the plastic is 0.15 W/m-K. The heat transfer coefficient on the outer surface of the sleeve exposed to air is 25 W/[latex]m^{2}[/latex]-K. Due to the addition of the plastic cover, the heat transfer from the wire to the ambient will
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Given data: } r_{o} &=1 \mathrm{mm} \\ \text { Inner radius: } r_{i} &=0.5 \mathrm{mm} \\ k &=0.15 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{mK} \\ h_{o} &=25 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \mathrm{K}\\ \text{Critical radius,}\\ r_{c} &=\frac{k}{h_{0}}=\frac{0.15}{25} \\ &=6 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{m}=6 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex] As [latex] r_{o} \lt r_{c^{\prime}} [/latex] due to addition of plastic cover heat  transfer will increase till [latex] r_{o}=r_{c}[/latex] beyond that heat transfer will decrease.

question: Question 71 A brick wall [latex](k= 0.9\frac{W}{m.K})[/latex] of thickness 0.18m separate the warm air in a room from the cold ambient air. On a particular winter day, the outside air temperature is -5[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C and the room needs to be maintained at 27[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C. The heat transfer coefficient associated with outside air is [latex]20\frac{W}{m^{2} K}[/latex]  . Neglecting the convective resistance of the air inside the room, the heat loss, in[latex]\frac{W}{m^{2}}[/latex], is
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{aligned} k&=0.9 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{mK} \\ \delta&=0.18 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] T_{0}=-5^{\circ} \mathrm{C} ; \quad T_{1}=27^{\circ} \mathrm{C} ; \quad h_{0}=20 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \mathrm{K} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{Heat loss: }Q&=\frac{T_{1}-T_{0}}{\frac{\delta}{\mathrm{k} A}+\frac{1}{h_{0} A}} \\ \frac{Q}{A} &=\frac{T_{1}-T_{0}}{\frac{\delta}{k}+\frac{1}{h_{0}}} \\ q&=\frac{27-(-5)}{0.18+\frac{1}{20}} \quad \because q=\frac{Q}{A} \\ &=\frac{32}{0.2+0.05} = \frac{32}{0.25}\\ &=128 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 72 A solid sphere 1 of radius 'r' is placed inside a hollow, closed hemispherical surface 2 of radius '4r'. The shape factor [latex]F_{2-1}[/latex] is
solution: Applying reciprocity theorem, [latex] \begin{aligned} A_{1} F_{1-2} &=A_{2} F_{2-1} \qquad | \because F_{1-2}=1.| \\ 4 \pi R_{1}^{2} &=\left(2 \pi R_{2}^{2}+\pi R_{2}^{2}\right) F_{2-1} \\ R_{1} &=r \\ R_{2} &=4 r \\ 4 \pi \times r^{2} &=3 \pi \times(4 r)^{2} F_{2-1} \\ F_{2-1} &=\frac{4 \pi r^{2}}{48 \pi r^{2}}=\frac{1}{12} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 73 Saturated vapor is condensed to saturated liquid in a condenser. The heat capacity ratio is [latex]C_{r}=\frac{C_{min}}{C_{max}}[/latex]. The effectiveness [latex](\varepsilon )[/latex] of the condenser is
solution: For parallel [latex] \varepsilon=\frac{1-\exp \left[-N T U\left(1+C_{f}\right)\right]}{1+C_{r}}[/latex] For condenser, [latex] \begin{aligned} C_{\max } &=\infty \\ C_{r} &=0 \\ \varepsilon &=\frac{1-\exp [-\mathrm{NTU}]}{1} \end{aligned}[/latex] Therefore (D) is correct option. Considering counter-flow heat exchanger [latex] \frac{1-\exp \left[-N T U\left(1+C_{r}\right)\right]}{1-C_{f} \exp \left[-N T U\left(1+C_{r}\right)\right]}[/latex] [latex] \therefore \quad c_{r}=0 [/latex] [latex] 1-\exp (-N T U) [/latex]

question: Question 74 The ratio of momentum diffusivity (v) to thermal diffusivity ([latex]\alpha[/latex]), is called
solution: [latex]Pr=\frac{v}{\alpha }[/latex]

question: Question 75 A cylindrical uranium fuel rod of radius 5 mm in a nuclear reactor is generating heat at the rate of [latex]4\times 10^{7} Wm^{3}[/latex] . The rod is cooled by a liquid (convective heat transfer coefficient 1000 W/[latex]m^{2}[/latex]-K) at  [latex]25^{\circ}C[/latex]. At steady state, the surface temperature (in K) of the rod is
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{aligned} r&=5 \mathrm{mm}=0.005 \mathrm{m}\\ \therefore \quad &=2 r=2 \times 0.005=0.010 \mathrm{m} \\ q_{G} &=4 \times 10^{7} \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ h_{0} &=1000 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \mathrm{K} \\ T_{0} &=25^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \end{aligned}[/latex] For steady state heat transfer, Rate of heat generation in the rod = rate of convection heat transfer from rod surface to fluid [latex] \begin{aligned} q_{G} \times \text { volume of } \operatorname{rod} &=h_{0} A\left(T_{s}-T_{0}\right) \\ q_{G} \times \frac{\pi}{4} d^{2} l^{\prime} &=h_{0} \times \pi d l\left(T_{s}-T_{0}\right) \\ \frac{d q_{G}}{4} &=h_{0}\left(T_{s}-T_{0}\right) \\ \frac{0.010 \times 4 \times 10^{7}}{4} &=1000\left(T_{s}-25\right) \\ \text{or }\quad T_{s}-25 &=100\\ \text{or }\quad T_{s}&=100+25=125^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\\ &=(125+273) \mathrm{K}=398 \mathrm{K} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 76 A balanced counterflow heat exchanger has a surface area of 20 [latex]m^{2}[/latex]  and overall heat transfer coefficient of 20 W/[latex]m^{2}[/latex] -K. Air ([latex]C_{p}[/latex] =1000 J/kg-K) entering at 0.4 kg/s and 280 K is to be preheated by the air leaving the system at 0.4 kg/s and 300 K. The outlet temperature (in K) of the preheated air is
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{aligned} A&=20 \mathrm{m}^{3} ; \quad U=20 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \mathrm{K} ; \quad c_{p h}=1000 \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{kg} \mathrm{K} \\ m_{c}&=0.4 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{s} ; \quad T_{c 1}=280 \mathrm{K} ; \quad m_{h}=0.4 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{s} \\ T_{h 2}&=300 \mathrm{K} ; \quad T_{c 2}=? \end{aligned}[/latex] By energy balance, Heat lost by hot fluid = Heat gained by cold fluid [latex] m_{h} c_{p h}\left(T_{h 1}-T_{h 2}\right)=m_{c} c_{p c}\left(T_{c 2}-T_{c 1}\right) [/latex] [latex] \text{or }\quad T_{h 1}-T_{h 2}=T_{c 2}-T_{c 1} \quad \because m_{h} c_{p h}=m_{c} c_{p c}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} T_{h 1}-T_{c 2} &=T_{h 2}-T_{c 1} \\ \theta_{1} &=\theta_{2} \\ \text { If } \theta_{1}&=\theta_{2} \text { , then } L M T D=\theta_{1}=\theta_{2} \\ Q &=A U L M T D \\ Q &=A U \times \theta_{1} \\ &=20 \times 20 \times\left(T_{h 2}-T_{c 1}\right) \\ &=400(300-280)=8000 \mathrm{kW} \\ \text{also }\quad Q&=m_{c} c_{p c}\left(T_{c 2}-T_{c 1}\right) \\ \therefore \quad 8000 &=0.4 \times 1000\left(T_{c 2}-280\right) \\ 20&=T_{c 2}-280 \\ \text{or}\quad T_{c 2}&=300^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \end{aligned} [/latex] Alternatively: Given data: [latex] A=20 \mathrm{m}^{3} ; U=20 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \mathrm{K} ; \quad [/latex] [latex] c_{\mathrm{ph}}=1000 \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{kgK} [/latex] [latex] m_{c}=0.4 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{s} ; \quad T_{c 1}=280 \mathrm{K} ; \quad m_{h}=0.4 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{s} [/latex] [latex] T_{h 2}=300 \mathrm{K} ; \quad T_{c 2}=?[/latex] By energy balance, Heat lost by hot fluid = Heat gained by cold fluid [latex] m_{h} c_{p h}\left(T_{h 1}-T_{h 2}\right)=m_{c} c_{p c}\left(T_{c 2}-T_{c 1}\right) [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { or } T_{h 1}-T_{h 2} &=T_{c 2}-T_{c 1} \qquad \because m_{h} c_{p h}=m_{c} c_{p c} \\ T_{h 1}-300 &=T_{c 2}-280 \\ T_{h 1}-T_{c 2} &=300-280 \qquad \ldots(1) \\ T_{h 1}-T_{c 2} &=20 \\ \epsilon&=\frac{N T U}{N T U+1} \quad[ \text{For balancing heat exchanger}]\\ \frac{T_{h 1}-T_{h 2}}{T_{h 1}-T_{c 1}} &=\frac{1}{1+1} \\ \frac{T_{h 1}-300}{T_{h 1}-280} &=\frac{1}{2} \\ 2 T_{h 1}-600 &=T_{h 1}-280 \\ T_{h 1} &=600-280=320 \mathrm{K} \end{aligned} [/latex] Substitute the value of [latex]T_{h 1}=320 \mathrm{K} [/latex] in Eq. (1), we get [latex] 320-T_{c 2}=20 [/latex] [latex] \text{or }\quad T_{c 2}=300 \mathrm{K}[/latex]

question: Question 77 The total emissive power of a surface is 500 W/[latex]m^{2}[/latex] at a temperature [latex]T_{1}[/latex] and 1200 W/[latex]m^{2}[/latex] at a temperature [latex]T_{2}[/latex], where the temperatures are in Kelvin. Assuming the emissivity of the surface to be  constant, the ratio of the temperatures [latex]\frac{T_{1}}{T_{2}}[/latex]
solution: E(emmisive power) [latex] \propto T^{4} \quad(\because \in=\text { Constant }) [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{E_{1}}{E_{2}}&=\left(\frac{T_{1}}{T_{2}}\right)^{4} \\ \text{or} \quad \frac{T_{1}}{T_{2}}&=\left(\frac{500}{1200}\right)^{1 / 4}=0.803 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 78 In the laminar flow of air (Pr = 0.7) over a heated plate, if [latex]\delta[/latex] and [latex]\delta_{r}[/latex]  denote, respectively, the 
hydrodynamic and thermal boundary layer thicknesses, then
solution: Prandtl number, [latex] \begin{aligned} P r&=0.7\\ \text{also}\quad \mathrm{Pr}&=\frac{\delta}{\delta_{r}}\\ \therefore 0.7&=\frac{\delta}{\delta_{r}}\\ \text{or }\quad \delta&=0.7 \delta_{r}\\ \therefore \delta& \lt \delta_{r}\\ \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 79 If a foam insulation is added to a 4 cm outer diameter pipe as shown in the figure, the critical radius of insulation (in cm) is _____________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} k_{\text {loam }}&=0.1 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{mK}\\ h_{0}&=2 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \mathrm{K} \\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Critical radius, [latex] \begin{aligned} r_{c} &=\frac{k_{\text {foam }}}{h_{0}} \text { for a pipe } \\ &=\frac{0.1}{2}=0.05 \mathrm{m}=5 \mathrm{cm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 80 A 10 mm diameter electrical conductor is covered by an insulation of 2 mm thickness. The conductivity of the insulation is 0.08 W/m-K and the convection coefficient at the insulation surface is 10 W/[latex]m^{2}[/latex]-K. Addition of further insulation of the same material will
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} d_{i} &=10 \mathrm{mm} \\ \therefore \qquad r_{i} &=\frac{d}{2}=\frac{10}{2}=5 \mathrm{mm} \\ t &=2 \mathrm{mm} \\ \therefore \qquad r_{0} &=r_{i}+t \\ &=5+2=7 \mathrm{mm}\\ k &=0.08 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{mK} \\ h_{0} &=10 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \mathrm{K} \end{aligned} [/latex] Critical radius, [latex] \begin{aligned} r_{c} &=\frac{k}{h_{0}}=\frac{0.08}{10} \\ &=0.008 \mathrm{m}=8 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] A s_{0}, r_{0}, [/latex] the heat loss increase to a maximum and then then decrease heat loss by addition of insulation.

options.C: increase heat loss to a maximum and then decrease heat loss
options.D: decrease heat loss to a minimum and then increase heat loss

question: Question 81 For flow through a pipe of radius R, the velocity and temperature distribution are as follows  [latex]u(r,x)=C_{1} [/latex]  and [latex]T(r,x)=C_{2}[1-(\frac{r}{R})^{3}],[/latex] where [latex]C_{1}[/latex]   and [latex]C_{2}[/latex]   are constants.  The bulk mean temperature is given by [latex]T_{m}=\frac{2}{U_{m}R^{2}}\int_{0}^{R}u(r,x)T(r,x)rdr[/latex] , with [latex]U_{m}[/latex]  being the mean velocity of flow. The value of [latex]T_{m}[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} u(r, x)&=C_{1} \\ T(r, x)&=C_{2}\left[1-\left(\frac{r}{R}\right)^{3}\right] \\ T_{m}&=\frac{2}{U_{m} R^{2}} \int_{0}^{R} u(r, x) T(r, x) r d r \\ &=\frac{2}{U_{m} R^{2}} \int_{0}^{R} C_{1} \times C_{2}\left[1-\left(\frac{r}{R}\right)^{3}\right] r d r \\ &=\frac{2 C_{1} C_{2}}{U_{m} R^{2}} \int_{0}^{R}\left[1-\left(\frac{r}{R}\right)^{3}\right] r d r \\ &=\frac{2 C_{1} C_{2}}{U_{m} R^{2}} \int_{0}^{R}\left(r-\frac{r^{4}}{R^{3}}\right) d r \\ &=\frac{2 C_{1} C_{2}}{U_{m} R^{2}}\left[\frac{r^{2}}{2}-\frac{r^{5}}{5 R^{3}}\right]_{0}^{R}\\ &=\frac{2 C_{1} C_{2}}{U_{m} R^{2}}\left[\frac{R^{2}}{2}-\frac{R^{5}}{5 R^{3}}\right] \\ &=\frac{2 C_{1} C_{2}}{U_{m} R^{2}}\left[\frac{R^{2}}{2}-\frac{R^{2}}{5}\right] \\ &=\frac{2 C_{1} C_{2}}{U_{m} R^{2}}\left[\frac{5 R^{2}-2 R^{2}}{10}\right] \\ &=\frac{2 C_{1} C_{2}}{U_{m} R^{2}} \times \frac{3}{10} R^{2}=\frac{0.6 C_{1} C_{2}}{U_{m}} \quad\ldots(i) \end{aligned}[/latex] since [latex] u(r, x)=C_{1}[/latex], constant [latex]U_{m}=C_{1} [/latex] Substituting [latex]U_{m}=C_{1} [/latex] in above Eq. (i), we get [latex] T_{m}=\frac{0.6 C_{1} C_{2}}{C_{1}}=0.6 C_{2}[/latex]

question: Question 82 For flow of viscous fluid over a flat plate, if the fluid temperature is the same as the plate temperature, the thermal boundary layer is
solution: For the flow of viscous fluid over a flat plate if the fluid temperature is the same as the plate temperature the thermal boundary layer is not formed at all because boundary layer formation took place if there is some difference in fluid property of no slip layer and remaining fluid. As here given that fluid is viscous and flowing over a flat plate. Here, definitely a kinematic boundary layer will be formed but as there is no temperature difference so no formation of thermal boundary layer.

options.A: thinner than the velocity boundary layer
options.B: thicker than the velocity boundary layer
options.C: of the same thickness as the velocity boundary layer

question: Question 83 The Blasius equation related to boundary layer theory is a
solution: [latex]2 \frac{d^{3} f}{d \eta^{3}}+f \frac{d^{2} f}{d \eta^{2}}=0 [/latex] third-order non-linear differential equation.

question: Question 84 Two infinite parallel plates are placed at a certain distance apart. An infinite radiation shield is inserted between the plates without touching any of them to reduce heat exchange between the plates. Assume that the emissivities of plates and radiation shield are equal. The ratio of the net heat exchange between the plates with and without the shield is
solution: [latex]\epsilon_{1}=\epsilon_{s}=\epsilon_{2}=\epsilon[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \mathrm{R}(\text { with N shields})&=(N+1)\left(\frac{2}{\epsilon}-1\right) \\ \text { R(without shield) }&=\frac{2}{\epsilon}-1 \\ \left(\frac{Q}{A}\right)_{\text {with } N \text { shield }}&=\frac{1}{N+1}\left(\frac{Q}{A}\right)_{\text {without shild }} \\ \therefore \frac{Q_{\text {with shield }}}{Q_{\text {without shield }}}=\frac{1}{N+1}&=\frac{1}{2} \quad(\because N=1) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 85 Water flows through a tube of diameter 25 mm at an average velocity of 1.0 m/s. The properties of water are [latex]\rho =1000 kg/m^{3}[/latex] , [latex]\mu =7.25\times 10^{-4} N.s/m^{2}[/latex] , [latex]k=0.625 W/m.K, P_{r}=4.85[/latex].  Using [latex]Nu=0.023 Re^{0.8} Pr^{0.4}[/latex],  the convective heat transfer coefficient (in [latex]W/m^{2}.K[/latex] )is______
solution: Reynolds number, [latex] \begin{aligned} \operatorname{Re} &=\frac{\rho V d}{\mu}=\frac{1000 \times 1 \times 25 \times 10^{-3}}{7.25 \times 10^{-4}} \\ &=34482.75 \\ \operatorname{Pr} &=4.85 \\ \mathrm{Nu} &=0.023 \mathrm{Re}^{0.8} \mathrm{Pr} .^{0.4} \\ \mathrm{Nu} &=0.023 \times(34482.758)^{0.8}(4.85)^{0.4} \\ &=184.546 \\ \text { also, } \quad \mathrm{Nu} &=\frac{h d}{k} \\ \text { or } \quad h &=\frac{\mathrm{Nuk}}{d}=\frac{184.546 \times 0.625}{25 \times 10^{-3}}\\ &=4613.66 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \mathrm{K} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 86 A plane wall has a thermal conductivity of 1.15 W/m.K.  If the inner surface is at 1100[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C and the outer surface is at 350[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C, then the design thickness (in meter) of the wall to maintain a steady heat flux of 2500 W/[latex]m^{2}[/latex] should be _______
solution: [latex] \begin{aligned} k&=1.15 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{mK} ;\; T_{1}=1100^{o};\;T_{2}=350^{o}C\\ q&=2500 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m}^{2}\\ \mathrm{T}_{1}&=1100^{\circ} \mathrm{C}_{i}, T_{2}=350^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \\ Q&=\frac{T_{1}-T_{2}}{R_{t}} \\ \frac{Q}{A}&=\frac{k\left(T_{1}-T_{2}\right)}{\delta} \\ q&=\frac{k\left(T_{1}-T_{2}\right)}{\delta} \\ 2500&=\frac{1.15(1100-350)}{\delta} \\ \text{or}\quad \delta&=0.345 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 87 Match Group A with Group B:

question: Question 89 A double -price counter-flow heat exchanger transfers heat between two water streams. Tube side water at 19 liters/s is heated from 10[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C to 38[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C. Shell side, water at 25 liters/s is entering at 46[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C. Assume constant properties of water, destiny is 1000kg/[latex]m^{3}[/latex] and specific heat is 4186 J/kg.K. The LMTD (in [latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C) is ________
solution: Given data: [latex] T_{h 1}=46^{\circ} \mathrm{C} ; \quad T_{n 2}=? ; \quad T_{c 1}=10^{\circ} \mathrm{C} ; \quad T_{c 2}=38^{\circ} \mathrm{C} [/latex] [latex] \rho_{\text {water }}=1000 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3} [/latex] [latex] m_{c}=19 \mathrm{L} / \mathrm{s}, m_{n}=25 \mathrm{L} / \mathrm{s} [/latex] From energy balance, [latex] \begin{aligned} m_{c} c_{c}\left(T_{c 2}-T_{c 1}\right)&=m_{h} c_{h}\left(T_{h 1}-T_{h 2}\right) \\ 19 \times(38-10) &=25\left(46-T_{h_{2}}\right) \\ \text { or } \quad T_{h_{2}} &=46-\frac{19 \times 28}{25}=24.72^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \\ \Delta T_{1} &=T_{h_{1}}-T_{c_{2}}=46-38=8^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \\ \Delta T_{2} &=T_{h_{2}}-T_{G}=24.72-10 \\ &=14.72^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \\ \mathrm{LMTD} &=\frac{\Delta T_{1}-\Delta T_{2}}{\ln \left(\frac{\Delta T_{1}}{\Delta T_{2}}\right)} \\ &=\frac{8-14.72}{\ln \left(\frac{8}{14.72}\right)}=\frac{6.72}{0.60976} \\ &=11.02^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 90 A solid sphere of radius [latex]r_{1}=20[/latex] mm is placed concentrically inside a hollow sphere of radius  [latex]r_{2}=30[/latex] mm as shown in the figure The view factor [latex]F_{21}[/latex] for radiation heat transfer is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} F_{11}+F_{12} &=1 \\ F_{11} &=0 \\ \therefore \quad F_{12}&=1 \end{aligned} [/latex] Applying reciprocity theorem, [latex] \begin{aligned} A_{1} F_{12}&=A_{2} F_{21}\\ \text{or} \quad F_{21} &=\frac{A_{1}}{A_{2}} F_{12}=\frac{4 \pi r_{1}^{2}}{4 \pi r_{2}^{2}} F_{12} \\ &=\left(\frac{r_{1}}{r_{2}}\right)^{2}=\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)^{2}=\frac{4}{9} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 91 Heat transfer through a composite wall is shown in figure. Both the sections of the wall have equal thickness ([latex]l[/latex]). The conductivity of one section is k and that of the other is 2k. The left face of the wall is at 600 K and the right face is at 300 K. The interface temperature [latex]T_{i}[/latex] (in K) of the composite wall is  _______
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{aligned} T_{1}&=600 \mathrm{K} \\ T_{2}&=300 \mathrm{K} \end{aligned}[/latex] For steady state heat transfer, Heat flow through layer-1 = Heat flow through layer-2 [latex] \begin{aligned} Q&=Q \\ \frac{T_{1}-T_{i}}{l / k A}&=\frac{T_{i}-T_{2}}{l / 2 k A} \\ \frac{k A\left(T_{1}-T_{i}\right)}{l}&=\frac{2 k A\left(T_{i}-T_{2}\right)}{l}\\ \text{or }\quad T_{1}-T_{i}&=2 T_{i}-2 T_{2} \\ \text{or }\quad T_{1}+2 T_{2}&=3 T_{i} \\ \text{or }\quad T_{i} &=\frac{T_{1}+2 T_{2}}{3} \\ &=\frac{600+2 \times 300}{3}=400^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 92 Consider a long cylindrical tube of inner and outer radii, [latex]r_{i}[/latex]  and  [latex]r_{o}[/latex] respectively, length, L and thermal conductivity, k.  Its inner and outer surfaces are maintained at [latex]T_{i}[/latex]  and [latex]T_{o}[/latex], respectively  ([latex]T_{i} \gt T_{o}[/latex]).  Assuming one-dimensional steady state heat conduction in the radial direction, the thermal resistance in the wall of the tube is
solution: For one dimensional steady state heat conduction in radial direction for hollow cylinder thermal resistance in the wall of tube is [latex]\frac{1}{2\pi kL}ln\left ( \frac{r_{o}}{r_{i}} \right )[/latex]

question: Question 93 In a concentric counter flow heat exchanger, water flows through the inner tube at 25[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C and leaves at 42[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C. The engine oil enters at 100[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C and flows in the annular flow passage. The exit temperature of the engine oil is 50[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C. Mass flow rate of water and the engine oil are 1.5 kg/s and 1 kg/s, respectively. The specific heat of water and oil are 4178 J/kg.K and 2130 J/kg.K, respectively. The effectiveness of this heat exchanger is _______
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{aligned} c_{c}=4178 \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{kgK} ; c_{h}&=2130 \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{kgK} \\ m_{c}=1.5 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{s} ; m_{h}&=1 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{s} \\ C_{\min }=& c_{h} m_{h}=2130 \times 1=2130 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{k} \\ C_{\max }=& c_{c} m_{c}=4178 \times 1.5 \\ =& 6267 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{K} \\ \Delta T_{1}=& 100-42=58^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \\ \Delta T_{2}=& 50-25=25^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \\ \Delta T_{l m} =&\frac{\Delta T_{1}-\Delta T_{2}}{\ln \left(\frac{\Delta T_{1}}{\Delta T_{2}}\right)} \\ =& \ln \left(\frac{58}{25}\right)=39.21^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \\ Q=& \mathrm{UA} \Delta T_{\mathrm{Im}} \\ \text{ also}\quad Q=& m_{c} c_{\mathrm{c}}\left(T_{\mathrm{c} 2}-T_{\mathrm{c} 1}\right) \\ \therefore \quad UA \Delta T_{l m}=&m_{c} c_{c}\left(T_{c 2}-T_{c 1}\right) \\ U A =&\frac{4178 \times 1.5(42-25)}{39.21} \\ =&2717.138 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{K} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \mathrm{NTU} &=\frac{\mathrm{UA}}{\mathrm{C}_{\min }}=\frac{2717}{2130}=1.2756 \\ C &=\frac{C_{\min }}{C_{\max }}=\frac{2130}{6267}=0.34 \\ &=\frac{1-\exp [-N T U(1-C)]}{1-C \exp [-N T U(1-C)]} \\ &=\frac{1-\exp [-1.2756 \times 0.66]}{1-0.34 \exp [1-2756 \times 0.66]} \\ &=\frac{1-0.43}{1-0.34 \times 0.43}=0.6676\\ Alternatively:\\ \epsilon &=\frac{T_{h_{1}}-T_{h_{2}}}{T_{h_{1}}-T_{c_{1}}} \\ &=\frac{100-50}{100-25} \\ &=\frac{50}{75}=\frac{2}{3}=0.6667 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 94 A material P of thickness 1 mm is sandwiched between two steel slabs, as shown in the figure below. A heat flux 10 [latex]kW/m^{2}[/latex] is supplied to one of the steel slabs as shown. The boundary temperatures of the slabs are indicated in the figure. Assume thermal conductivity of this steel is 10 W/m.K. Considering one-dimensional steady state heat conduction for the configuration, the thermal conductivity (k, in W/m.K) of material P is _______
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{aligned} x &=1 \mathrm{mm}=0.001 \mathrm{m} \\ \mathrm{q}^{\prime \prime} &=10 \mathrm{kW} / \mathrm{m}^{2}=10000 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \\ k_{s} &=10 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{mK} \\ \delta &=20 \mathrm{mm}=0.02 \mathrm{m} \\ T_{1} &=500 \mathrm{K} \\ T_{2} &=360 \mathrm{K} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { Heat flow: } Q&=\frac{T_{1}-T_{2}}{\frac{\delta}{k_{\mathrm{s}} A}+\frac{x}{k A}+\frac{\delta}{k_{\mathrm{s}} A}} \\ Q &=\frac{T_{1}-T_{2}}{\frac{2 \delta}{k_{s} A}+\frac{x}{k A}} \\ \frac{Q}{A}&= \frac{T_{1}-T_{2}}{\frac{2 \delta}{k_{s}}+\frac{x}{k}} \\ q^{\prime \prime}&=\frac{\frac{T_{1}-T_{2}}{2 \delta}+\frac{x}{k}}{k_{s}} \\ or q^{\prime \prime}\left(\frac{2 \delta}{k_{s}}+\frac{x}{k}\right)&=T_{1}-T_{2} \\ 10000\left(\frac{2 \times 0.02}{10}+\frac{0.001}{k}\right)&=500-360 \\ 40+\frac{10}{k}&=140 \\ or \quad \frac{10}{k}&=140-40=100 \\ or \quad k=\frac{10}{100}&=0.1 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{mK} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 95 a hemispherical furnace of 1m radius has the inner surface (emissivity, [latex]\varepsilon =1[/latex]  ) of its roof maintained at 800K, while its floor ([latex]\varepsilon =0.5[/latex] ) is kept at 600K. Stefan-Boltzmann constant is [latex]5.668\times 10^{-8}W/m^{2}.K^{4}[/latex]. The net radiative heat transfer (in kW ) from the roof to the floor is _______
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{aligned} r&=1 \mathrm{m} \\ \epsilon_{1} &=1 \\ T_{1} &=800 \mathrm{K} \\ \epsilon_{2} &=0.5 \\ T_{2} &=600 \mathrm{K} \\ \sigma &=5.668 \times 10^{-8} \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \mathrm{K}^{4} \\ \left(F_{9}\right)_{1-2} &=\frac{1}{\frac{1-\epsilon_{1}}{\epsilon_{1}}+\frac{1}{F_{12}}+\frac{A_{1}}{A_{2}}\left(\frac{1-\epsilon_{1}}{\epsilon_{2}}\right)} \\ F_{21} &=1 \\ A_{1} F_{12} &=A_{2} F_{21}\\ \Rightarrow \quad F_{12}&=\frac{A_{2}}{A_{1}}=\frac{\pi r^{2}}{2 \pi r^{2}}=\frac{1}{2} \\ \therefore \quad F&=\frac{1}{\left(\frac{1-1}{1}\right)+2+2\left(\frac{1-0.5}{0.5}\right)} \\ \quad=\frac{1}{4}&=0.25 \\ \therefore \quad Q_{1-2} &=\sigma A\left(F_{9}\right)_{1-2}\left[T_{1}^{4}-T_{2}^{4}\right] \\ Q_{12} &=5.668 \times 2 \times \pi \times(1)^{2} \\ & \times 0.25\left(800^{4}-600^{4}\right) \times 10^{-8} \\ Q_{12} &=24916.528 \mathrm{W}=24.916 \mathrm{kW} \end{aligned}[/latex]

This heat exchanger is

question: Question 97 For laminar forced convection over a flat plate, if the free stream velocity increases by a factor of 2, the average heat transfer coefficient
solution: For the laminar flow over flat plate, [latex] \mathrm{Re} \lt 3 \times 10^{5}[/latex] Nusselt number, [latex] \begin{aligned} & N_{u}=\frac{h l}{k}=0.664 \mathrm{Re}^{1 / 2} \mathrm{Pr}^{1 / 3} \\ \text { where } \mathrm{Re}&=\frac{U l}{\mathrm{v}} \\ \therefore \qquad \frac{h l}{k}&=0.664 \times\left(\frac{U l}{\mathrm{v}}\right)^{1 / 2} \times \mathrm{Pr}^{1 / 3}\\ h &\propto U^{1 / 2}\\ \frac{h_{2}}{h_{1}} &=\left(\frac{U_{2}}{U_{1}}\right)^{1 / 2} \\ &=\left(\frac{2 U_{2}}{U_{1}}\right)^{1 / 2}=\sqrt{2}\\ \text{or }\quad h_{2}&=\sqrt{2} h_{1}\\ \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 98 The non-dimensional fluid temperature profile near the surface of a convectively cooled flat plate is given by [latex]\frac{T_W-T}{T_W-T_\infty }=a+b\frac{y}{L}+c\left ( \frac{y}{L} \right )^2[/latex], where y is measured perpendicular to the plate, [latex]L[/latex]  is the plate length, and a, b and c are arbitrary constants. [latex]T_{W}[/latex]  and [latex]T_{\infty}[/latex]  are wall and ambient temperatures, respectively. If the thermal conductivity of the fluid is [latex]k[/latex]   and the wall heat flux is [latex]q''[/latex], the Nusselt number [latex]N_u=\frac{q''}{T_W-T_\infty }\frac{L}{k}[/latex]  is  equal to
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} q^{\prime \prime} &=-\left.k \frac{\partial T}{\partial y}\right|_{y=0} \\ &=h\left(T_{w}-T_{\infty}\right) \\ T_{w}-T &=\left(T_{w}-T_{\infty}\right)\left[a+\frac{b y}{L}+c\left(\frac{y}{L}\right)^{2}\right] \\ \frac{\partial T}{\partial y} & =\left(T_{w}-T_{\infty}\right)\left[\frac{b}{L}+\frac{2 c}{L^{2}} y\right] \\ -\left.\frac{\partial T}{\partial y}\right|_{y=0} &=\left(T_{w}-T_{\infty}\right) \frac{b}{L} \\ \text{or} \quad q^{\prime \prime}&=k\left(T_{w}-T_{\infty}\right) \frac{b}{L} \\ \therefore \quad N u &=\frac{q^{\prime \prime}}{T_{w}-T_{\infty}} \frac{L}{k}=b \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 99 Consider one dimensional steady state heat conduction across a wall (as shown in figure below) of thickness 30 mm and thermal conductivity 15 W/m.K. At x = 0, a constant heat flux, [latex]q''= 1\times 10^5 W/m^2[/latex]  is applied. On the other side of the wall, heat is removed from the wall by convection with a fluid at 25[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C and heat transfer coefficient of 250 [latex]W/m^2[/latex] K. The temperature  (in [latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C), at x = 0 is _______
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{aligned} \delta&=30 \mathrm{mm}=0.03 \mathrm{m} ; \quad k=15 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{mK} \\ q^{\prime \prime}&=1 \times 10^{5} \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m}^{2} ; \quad T_{\infty}=25^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \\ h&=250 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \mathrm{K} \end{aligned}[/latex] Heat transfer due to convection from outside surface per unit area: [latex] \begin{aligned} q^{\prime \prime} &=\frac{Q}{A}=h\left(T_{2}-T_{\infty}\right) \\ 1 \times 10^{5} &=250\left(T_{2}-25\right) \\ \text{or}\qquad T_{2} &=425^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \end{aligned}[/latex] Heat transfer through wall per unit area, [latex] \begin{aligned} q^{\prime \prime} &=\frac{k\left(T_{1}-T_{2}\right)}{\delta} \\ 1 \times 10^{5} &=\frac{15\left(T_{1}-425\right)}{0.03}\\ \text{or }\qquad T_{1}&=625^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \end{aligned}[/latex]
